reviewText:
For a film about nothing, Seven Psychopaths is one of the most delightful films of the year. Writer/director Martin McDonagh re-teams with Colin Farrell from the 2008 classic In Bruges and peppers his film with a terrific ensemble cast that includes Sam Rockwell, Christopher Walken, Woody Harrelson, Tom Waits, Kevin Corrigan, and Harry Dean Stanton. The film's plot is a wonderful slice of metafiction that deliberately blurs the line between what's actually happening and what's just happening in the script the main character is writing. With that in mind, Seven Psychopaths isn't really about anything yet it has one of the most ingenious scripts of the year.

The film opens with two hit men (Michael Pitt and Michael Stuhlbarg) discussing, at length, shooting a woman through the eyes. As they banter back-and-forth a masked man nonchalantly walks up behind them and shoots them both. This is Psychopath No. 1. From here we meet Marty (Farrell), an alcoholic screenwriter working on his latest script entitled `Seven Psychopaths.' The problem is he doesn't yet know who the seven psychopaths are. His friend Billy Bickle (Rockwell), an unemployed actor who, with his partner Hans (Walken), moonlights as a dog thief, attempts to provide him with unwanted assistance. When Billy kidnaps a Shih Tzu from Charlie (Harrelson), a violent gangster, Billy, Marty, and Hans find themselves running for their lives. This is intercut with Marty building his own script, with the help of some outside ideas.

Somehow, even when the film jumps into Marty's own fictional narrative it remains fascinating. One sequence involves a Quaker (Stanton) getting revenge for the death of his daughter and there's an eloquent, macabre sequence narrated by Zachariah Rigby (Waits). The film is consistently entertaining and endlessly fascinating.

This is McDonagh's second film, but as an acclaimed playwright he's well-versed in his craft. Seven Psychopaths is a slight departure from In Bruges tonally, but it has the same dark humor and the same mark of his genius. His screenplay is brilliantly plotted; a hilarious and violent work with memorable dialogue complemented by his eye for casting and his prowess as a director. There seems to be a Quentin Tarantino/Guy Ritchie influence here, yet he puts his unique stamp on the formula and creates a delightfully demented crime film that is destined to become a cult classic.

The performances are showy and I'm not sure any will be considered Oscar-worthy, but they are very fun to watch. Walken hasn't given a performance this inspired in years. His energetic and hilarious performance teeters on the edge of self-parody at times, but it's very self-aware and possibly the funniest acting in the film. Harrelson demonstrates his enviable range here with his ability to move from one extreme to the other; in one moment, he's a frightening psychopath and in another he's hilarious...Sometimes at the same time. Tom Waits brings his own quirkiness to a role that only he would be able to create in such a way. Rockwell meanwhile nearly steals the show from everyone in a perfect Rockwell-type role. Farrell does a fine job, but he seems to allow the other actors to take center stage.

I admit the film is bedazzling to a degree. So much is good about it; it's easy to forget it's not perfect. Towards the latter half of the film it becomes a little too meta for its own good and almost veers off-track, but McDonagh skillfully reels it back in before it loses traction.

Seven Psychopaths isn't a masterpiece, but I predict it will become an often-seen classic among many viewers and will be enjoyed through repeat viewings in the coming years. It doesn't quite touch the brilliance of In Bruges, but it is a cartoonishly fun film that expertly blends ingenious writing, hilarity, and violence. It's one of the most original films of the year by far and certainly one of 2012's best.

If Roddy Doyle, Quentin Tarantino and the Coen brothers got drunk together one night, they'd almost certainly come up with a script like those of Martin McDonagh and his brother, John Michael. Martin McDonagh, already a successful playwright, directed two gleefully bloody black comedies, the Oscar-winning short "Six Shooter" and the full-length "In Bruges." Not to be outdone, John Michael McDonagh came up with his own nihilistic comic romp, "The Guard."

"Seven Psychopaths," Martin's latest movie, is the first McDonagh flick not to feature Brendan Gleeson. But although Gleeson is missed, the ensemble cast makes up for his absence. Foremost among them is Sam Rockwell as Billy Bickle, an aspiring actor who pays the bills by running a dognapping racket with his friend Hans (Christopher Walken). Rockwell, whose character can best be described as a hyperactive child on crack, brims over with ideas for the latest screenplay by his seriously blocked, seriously alcoholic best pal Martin (Colin Farrell, who also starred in "In Bruges"). Soon, however, major trouble heads the way of Billy, Martin, and Hans, after Billy's latest dognap victim turns out to be the beloved pet of crazed mobster Charlie Costello (Woody Harrelson).

Like its predecessors, "Seven Psychopaths" is wildly funny, consistently inventive, and over-the-top violent. I will preserve its plot twists for you to discover for yourself. For me it didn't have as much bloody meat on its bones as "In Bruges" or "The Guard," but it does raise some interesting connections between movie violence and real-life violence. (Remember how Silvio on "The Sopranos" loved to do his "Godfather" impressions? "Seven Psychopaths" makes the same point, but much, much more strongly.) Rockwell steals the picture, but Walken, Harrelson and Tom Waits all offer amusing variations on criminal sociopathy, and Farrell is a likably befuddled straight man. With funny cameos by Harry Dean Stanton, Gabourey Sidibe, Michael Pitt, Michael Stuhlbarg and others, "Seven Psychopaths" is wild fun.

This is director (and writer) Martin McDonagh's third film and first since the very good "In Bruges" from 2008.  A pair of small time con men (Sam Rockwell and Christopher Walken) specializes in stealing dogs, then returning them for the reward.  Billy's (Rockwell) best friend Marty (Colin Farrell) is a wannabe screenwriter who only has the title for his movie (Seven Psychopaths) and a broad idea for a story.  Marty's biggest problem seems to be that he's drunk all the time.

Billy offers to help him with the story but Marty is intent on doing it himself.  Figuring he can give Marty some ideas, Billy runs an ad in a local trade paper, looking for reformed psychos to come in for an interview.  Yeah, the film is full of craziness.  This allows the always entertaining Tom Waits to show up as Zachariah, one of the seven psychos.

The films dognapping element becomes critical as Billy and Hans (Walken) kidnap a shih-tzu belonging to, yep, psycho crime lord Charlie (Woody Harrelson).  There is nobody better than Walken when it comes to playing offbeat characters and he doesn't disappoint.  While everybody makes contributions, this is Rockwell's movie.  His character is interesting, funny and provocative.  So is the movie.  It is a bit complicated, so you have to pay attention.  It is also extremely violent and the violence is pretty much just laughed away.  Such is this wonderful dark comedy.  It's absurd, messy, witty, smart and wildly entertaining.  One of the best of the year.

Back a few years ago, a writer/director by the name of Martin McDonagh emerged very heavily on the cinematic stage with the extremely black comedy IN BRUGES. It was hilariously funny, shockingly violent, utterly absurd at points as well as surprisingly human and touching. It also gave Colin Farrell possibly his best role ever. And with such an excellent film between them, what could they possibly do that could live up to the expectations set by that film?

They could reteam and make SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS, and it really does live up to the expectations.

SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS primarily follows Martin (Farrell), a screenwriter in Hollywood trying desperately to write his newest script which he calls "Seven Psychopaths". His best friend is Billy (Sam Rockwell), a struggling actor who runs a dog-kidnapping... excuse me, dog-borrowing business on the side with his partner Hans (Christopher Walken) in which they find wealthy dog-owners, take the dogs, and return them for the reward money. Unfortunately for all involved, they end up taking the wrong person's dog, and that person is Mr. Costello (Woody Harrelson), a crime boss who loves his little Shih Tzu above all other things. A brutal and deadly pursuit begins for Costello as he tries to retrieve his dog, while Martin becomes embroiled in this mad scheme. All the while, Martin is coming up with ideas for more psychopaths to use in his film, and also meeting them via an ad that Billy put in the paper specifically for psychopaths to tell their story to Martin, and one of those is the bunny-petting Zachariah (Tom Waits), who has quite the tale to tell. Lines between life and art start to gradually blur as the inevitable confrontation between the dog-nappers and the dog-napped comes ever closer.

Like IN BRUGES, SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS treads the very thin line between tragedy and comedy with some absolutely devastating moments, but then somehow finds a way to make itself the funniest film I've seen this year with some absolutely masterful performances that will likely be forgotten when Awards Season kicks off. Sam Rockwell continues his streak of scene-stealing performances as Billy, who is rightly considered one of the seven psychopaths of the title. Colin Farrell is forced to play straight man to the likes of Rockwell and Walken and does a nicely nuanced job of it. Harrelson is menacing and violently unpredictable enough to be a good villain, but also his obsessive love of his dog makes his bad guy increasingly absurd and funny. Waits does a really nice job with what must be a fun role to play and a really interesting character to watch. Also appearing in the film are Abbie Cornish as Martin's on-off girlfriend, Linda Bright Clay as Hans' wife and Olga Kurlyenko as Billy's secret girlfriend. This is really the only problem that I had with the film is that the female characters are largely ignored or marginalized, but there may be method to McDonagh's madness as there is a conversation in the film about Martin's screenplay lacking anything beyond one-dimensional female characters (which likely speaks to the metatext of the entire film). But when all is said and truly done, it's Walken who walks away with this picture. It's a performance of wit, sensitivity, genuine humanity, some menace and if nothing else, the "put your hands up" scene is something that will be in the annals of film comedy history.

There are so many moments of high humor in this film, it's hard to enumerate them, but what's perhaps most important about this film is the discussion about the film as the film is going on between its characters. Billy sees this whole story AS a film, and Martin looks to include stories from the film in his film. The film becomes a semi-satire of itself as it goes on, much like Drew Goddard and Joss Whedon's THE CABIN IN THE WOODS. As that film provided a metatextual satire of horror film conventions, SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS offers up satire of the post-Tarantino crime genre, with philosophical hitmen, final shootouts, Mexican standoffs, etcetera. McDonagh makes all of the film's drama, comedy and action work with a wink in its eye and gallows humor in its heart.

It's also important to know that if you liked IN BRUGES, then in all likelihood, you will really enjoy this film. But if you didn't care for IN BRUGES, you probably won't like this film. SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS, like IN BRUGES, does have some pretty massive tonal shifts from hilarious comedy to gut-wrenching tragedy and that can be hard to swallow for some audiences. It may not seem like it, but that is important to take into account.

SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS is one of those rare great films that succeeds on all the levels it reaches for, but is strange enough to leave you wondering long after the credits roll... and believe me, STAY FOR THE CREDITS. It's the perfect coda to a film like this.

4.5/5 Stars.

Had the wonderful opportunity to get this screened a couple of months ago in Los Angeles. I didn't know what to expect except from the synopsis. All I knew it that it had a great cast: Woody Harrelson, Sam Rockwell, Colin Farrell, Christopher Walken etc. That was enough for me to RVSP for the movie. Then I learned it was from upcoming director Martin McDonagh whose gotten critically acclaim for his work. Then I knew I was in for quite an evening.

I gotta say it delivered the goods. Dark comedies are definitely a great genre especially if handled well. McDonagh utilizes his talent very well. I and the screening audience definitely laughed at every turn.

All the performances were very good. I am not a big Colin Farrel fan, but he was perfect as "Marty"-the screenwriter who doesn't know what he's gotten himself into when he puts an ad to interview psychopaths for his screenplay "Seven Psychopaths" at the request of his friend Billy (Sam Rockwell). Sam Rockwell was great as Billy. Woody Harrelson as the mafia boss. Christopher Walken was great as Hans.

One thing that always sticks out for me when I enjoy a movie is noticing how well the cast enjoys themselves in playing their roles. Every actor in the movie you can tell has a lot of fun with the roles they have especially Woody Harrelson and Sam Rockwell who really dominate their screen time.

If you're in the mood for something totally different, and want to laugh and laugh hard then this is the movie for you.

The Irish playwright and scenarist Martin McDonagh is hands-down the world's best creator of black comedy today.  He brings the insanity of the contemporary world -- and of Hollywood -- to nis newest film, Seven Psychopaths, which he wrote and directed.  Viewers familiar with his theatrical works like The Lieutenant of Inishmore and The Cripple of Inishmaan or Pillowman will love this new film.  McDonagh has a lightness of touch that combined with his acute perceptiveness of the absurd create tears of laughter throughout this zany motion picture.  You won't want to miss it.

Some 3-4 years ago, director Martin McDonagh teamed up with Colin Farrell in an absurd but very funny crime comedy called "In Bruges". I loved that movie (and not just because it was filmed in the Belgian city of Bruges, where I spent my high school years). Now comes another crime comedy from the same team.

"Seven Psychopaths" (2012 release; 110 min.) brings the story of Marty (played by Farrell), a struggling writer who is working on a movie script called "Seven Psychopaths". His buddy Billy (played by Sam Rockwell) is volunteering to help in any way possible. At some point Billy steals a little dog, and only later do we learn that the dog's owner is Charlie (played by Woody Harrelson), a dangerous gangster who is out for revenge. Last, but certainly not least, there is Hans (played by Christopher Walken), a buddy of Billy's. There are a bunch of smaller characters in the movie. To be honest, I had a hard time keeping track of the multitude of characters, and the fact that part of the movie is a recreation of the script that Marty is writing. A script within the script, so to speak. After a while I simply let go of it all, and just watched the movie for what it is, regardless of the actual or percieved plot lines: another absurd (and I do mean that as a compliment) crime drama.

Couple of side comments: with apologies to Colin Farrell, but in my opinion Sam Rockwell steals the movie. His acting is sharp and he brings his character in a way that made me smile if not laugh out loud, just by seeing him. I also was surprised to see that this movie is not just playing at the art house here in Cincinnati (where I saw it), but also at a number of mainstream mulitplexes. The movie was not very well attended when I saw it this past weekend, and I can't imnagine that a dark and violent movie like this one, even with plenty of humor and comedy, will be a big hit, but I could be wrong of course. Bottom line is this: if you liked "In Bruges", which in style and approach is very similar to this one, you will love "Seven Psychopaths". If you found that "In Bruges" was not your cup of tea, save yourself the trouble and don't bother with this.

Martin McDonagh, among the best known Irish directors previously won an Oscar for the short movie Six shooter A Collection of 2005 Academy Award Nominated Short Films although he is perhaps best known for the acclaimed In Brugesalso starring Colin Farrell, a dark comedy with tragic overtones about two hitmen on the run. I first heard of this movie last year when I saw the movie The Guard directed by his brother Michael John. A trademark of the McDonaghs is dark humor mixed with some irony and perhaps even some philosophy together with some absurdity. As I loved The Guard so much and it has the biggest domestic box office of any Irish movie ever made, I looked forward to this latest movie with more than a little anticipation. If you're like me and like American directors who also write such as Tarantino with Reservoir Dogs and Kill Bill, or the Coen Brothers with No Country for Old Men, I think you will also like this. Seven Psychopaths centers around an Irish screenwriter nemed Martin played by Colin Farrell planning to write a movie about seven psychopaths. Life begins to imitate art as a similar tableau to the one he writes about starts to unfold in real life. Woody Harrelson plays Sam a local organised crime leader whose dog is kidnapped by Walken and Sam Rockwell's character who happen to be friends of Martin. Sam cares more about dogs than people. The real mixes with the imaginary in very intriguing ways, and kept the movie audience entertained. I particularly liked the scenes with the Vietnamese priest and the hooker, and the Quaker story. There is also a hit man with a white rabbit played by Tom Waits. The revelatory performance in this movie comes from Sam Rockwell when he helps out Martin with the screenplay lending some psychotic absurdity to the scenes although everyone is excellent. What I like is that McDonagh while clearly inspired by Tarantino and Coen imposes his unique style and does not kowtow to Hollywood conventions and delivers a movie that experiments with different styles of humor and yet manages to engross you so much in the moment that you do not attempt to guess the end. If you do you would probably guess wrong. I love how he works the opening scene with two hitmen discussing preparing for a hit and how the scene turns out. While I would not consider this better than say In Bruges there is a certain heaviness in the theme of In Bruges that is not present here and some people may prefer the more light hearted nature of this movie which is a highly welcome and worthy addition to the McDonagh repertoire. I hope the McDonagh brothers will work together as I think they could give the Coen brothers a run for their money. I think you will love it and I hope this was helpful.

I've been waiting for the release of Seven Psychopaths ever since I learned that Martin McDonagh was writing and directing. If you have seen In Bruges, you'll know that McDonagh has a dark sense of humor, not too far removed from something Quentin Tarantino might be involved with.

Does Seven Psychopaths match the brilliance of In Bruges? Not quite, but it's still an entertaining movie.

Marty (Farrell) is a struggling screenwriter, who has decided on little more than the title, Seven Psychopaths. The problem is, he wants his psychopaths to be Buddhist, and he can't see how they would go around killing people. He decides to make one Amish instead, for no particular reason. Marty doesn't have a clue about writing.

His friends, Billy (Rockwell) and Hans (Walken), make money by dognapping and returning the animals to their owners in order to claim the reward money. This backfires when they inadvertently take a dog belonging to Charlie (Harrelson), who is some kind of crime lord. You only have to read the tag on the collar of his beloved Shih Tzu to understand Charlie's outlook on life.

Seven Psychopaths is a comedy. It's also extremely violent at times, and has more than its fair share of foul language (including the word that almost every woman detests), with brief nudity and occasional racist remarks. But it's obvious that everything is tongue-in-cheek. It's almost impossible to mistake the movie for a serious drama; it's a fun ride, and the R-rated material does not seem offensive or out of place.

I've already mentioned Tarantino, and for good reason. The genre and setting are almost irrelevant; this is an exercise in style, and you'll either love it or hate it. Dialogue is everything in this type of movie and most of the writing is inventive, witty and intelligent. The opening scene is reminiscent of Pulp Fiction, with two hit men talking nonsense. The scene ends in an unexpected way, and I won't reveal it here, but it sets the tone for the whole movie.

McDonagh is aware of the course that Hollywood action movies are supposed to follow, and Seven Psychopaths challenges those expectations. One character suggests that they pitch a tent in the middle of the desert so they can just sit there and talk, rather than having a traditional shootout with the bad guys. In response, his friend asks whether this is a French movie. It's that kind of humor. Another interchange observes that women have a rough deal in this story; when they aren't being verbally abused, they are in danger of being removed permanently.

I won't say any more about the plot because it's enjoyable seeing things gradually unfold on the screen, except to say that my favorite scene featured Hans making a suggestion about how to end the movie. Walken's comic timing is excellent as always, and his scenes are funnier when you think about some of the characters he has played in the past.

The movie features good performances from Rockwell, Walken, Harrelson and Farrell in particular, although nobody else delivers a weak performance. The audience in my theater laughed often, and occasionally groaned at the unexpected violent scenes. If you go in expecting a dark comedy along the lines of In Bruges, Fargo, or The Guard, you'll likely enjoy the experience. The pacing feels just right.

One thing I should add is that it's best to sit through the credits, or you will miss the final scene.

I'm looking forward to the Blu-ray and the next McDonagh movie. It would be fun to see Brendan Gleeson involved too.

Being a big fan of "In Bruges," getting excited for writer, director, and now producer Martin McDonagh's latest film "Seven Psychopaths" was like second nature. "In Bruges" is begging for a revisit, but it added a lot of humor to hitmen and crime situations that usually try to be gritty or as serious as humanly possible in films before it. "In Bruges" had this uniqueness to it and "Seven Psychopaths" is even more creative and hilarious in comparison.

A struggling screenwriter named Marty (Colin Farrell) has an idea for his next screenplay; a movie entitled "Seven Psychopaths." The problem is Marty is having difficulty coming up with the actual story or the psychopaths for that matter and his alcoholism often gets the better of him. His strange best friend Billy (Sam Rockwell), who kidnaps dogs with a religious man named Hans (Christopher Walken) and returns them to get the reward, has extreme interest in helping Marty write his story. What Marty doesn't count on is Billy putting an ad in the newspaper that opens the door for all sorts of crazy individuals to contact him and know where he lives. Marty's thrown into a world he's never dreamt of because of it.

If you've seen the poster for this, it portrays Olga Kurylenko and Abbie Cornish as two of the seven psychopaths. Ignore this. They maybe have eight minutes of screen time between the two of them and other than being the girlfriends of a few of the main characters are mostly completely irrelevant to everything else going on. The opening of the film is extraordinary; mostly because the appearance of "Boardwalk Empire" alumni Michael Stuhlbarg and Michael Pitt was completely unexpected. Their "shot through the eyeball" conversation immediately sets the messy and eccentric tone of the film.

The original aspect of "Seven Psychopaths" resides in its writing. Marty is writing a movie called "Seven Psychopaths" during a film you're watching with the same name. The entire sequence where Marty, Billy, and Hans go out into the middle of nowhere to write the movie is incredible. Not only is it massively entertaining, but it gives you a number of different scenarios of how the film could play out and how Marty will decide to end his version of the movie. It's as if it shatters the fourth wall and then just keeps running for several miles.

There's also this hilarious sense of logic throughout the entire comedy. Sam Rockwell is the funniest he's ever been. He acts a bit off, but everything that comes out of his mouth is just hysterical. His version of how Marty's movie should end is his shining moment, but he steals the show whenever he's on screen or opens his mouth. Nearly every conversation is just absurd though, but it's so absurd that it makes way too much sense. The phrase, "That's just crazy enough to work!" was meant for this film.

The rest of the cast isn't wasted either. It's interesting that Mickey Rourke was originally supposed to portray Charlie since Woody Harrelson fits the role so well. His obsession with his dog makes the Charlie character completely unpredictable. Christopher Walken is really superb. He makes Hans seem so much more interesting than he really is and his rambling is often the voice of reason or so dry that it's laugh out loud funny. Tom Waits as Zachariah is captivating because of his backstory and fascination with bunnies. His motives along with his after credit sequence are just written so unusually that it's amusing.

There really isn't anything else out there like "Seven Psychopaths." If that Marvel movie about "Deadpool" ever gets off the ground, you can imagine it to be a lot like this; people getting killed left and right, blood everywhere, ridiculously hilarious conversations in between and during, and the entire experience leaving a smile on your face. There's also quite a bit buried beneath the laughs and the killing; the question of whether the afterlife is real and peace being more important than war. This comedy has a very sentimental center that catches you a bit off-guard, especially when it comes to the emotional ending. "Seven Psychopaths" is an automatic contender for the funniest and most original comedy of the year.
Indeed a masterpiece!
Didn't really connect with this film.
A bit ridiculous, but I think that's its charm.  A new fave!
This movie is so well written, and so well cast, and so well acted, and so well done.  Just see it.
Interesting to the end. I loved the twists and turns. Most surprising movie I've watched in a long time. TWO THUMBS UP!!!!!
Great movie

I don't get how many people don't understand this movie. the characters literally spell it out for you during the movie.
It's all about friendship and love. And art. It's a movie about writing a screenplay.
And if you think this is a failed Tarantino flick, The opening scene shows us the writers views of Tarantino movies.
I will watch this over and over again because it's cathartic and feel good.
Very cool story! Great actors, brilliant dialogues and fantastic sense of humor! Absolutely LOVED it!
This movie turned out to be one of my top 5 faves. Love everyone in it and storyline is hilarious.
Very unique film, one of a kind. Thrilling from the beginning to end.
Just not as good as it sounds lmao

If you like dark comedies, or just want to see a great movie, this is the one to watch. I went into it with no expectations, and half way through the movie I realized that I was watching something brilliant. It was so good that I've decided to write my first review ever in hopes that I may... perhaps sway any fence sitters to make the choice of watching it.
The cast is remarkable, everything about this movie was incredible. I don't usually laugh out loud when I'm alone, but this movie had me doing just that. How is it that I had never heard of this movie before? I don't know, but one thing is for sure, I will be watching it again and again, it's that good!
super funny movie. great if you need something to chill out and laugh with
Lots of action this is a good movie,  we really liked this one.
Honestly did not expect this to be so good. Was in it for Walkins. Honestly just. Wow.

I loved this movie. I haven't enjoyed a movie in a long time. This was perfect. I laughed out loud at many points. Christopher Walkens character is funny and human and good.

Idk how to describe this movie, really. Its dark, its funny, it might make you tear up, it might make you irritated. Its good. Give it a watch.
A great subversion of the bloody Tarantino-style revenge genre. It never looses the fun of being violent or irreverent but approaches it with a lot of heart and thought.
Cool film.  If you like the director's other films you'll enjoy this one.  Very chaotic told through a unique point of view.
This product does NOT work on American DVD players and ruined a gift idea. Please be more specific.
best ever
Definite must see if you like dark comedy, absurdity, and political incorrectness.
Love, love, love it! real good cast.
Just quirky enough to laugh and enjoy the movie.
awful plot, awful acting
Would recommend to others
My husband and I loved this movie so much we've decided to make an event night!
Good Movie! Worth the watch.

This is another great black comedy.  It's one of those stories where there's a groundwork that has to be established to continually build up the level of humor.  At first, I couldn't quite figure out where the story was going, but I stayed with it, and it grew crazier and funnier (and funnier still) over time, with constant twists and turns, as the disparate elements of the storyline came together.  It has a stellar cast who play the bizarre, off-beat characters -- roles that many of these actors are extremely skilled at and are well known for.  Like most black comedies, it has a good deal of violence and strong language, so it might not be everyone's cup of tea.  But, I loved it!
Was wondering when it was going to get good the entire time.
I rarely watch movies anymore, but its funny the characters were unique and the storytelling was unique.
Turned it off half way through because it was just too convoluted to keep my interest. You might like it though, give it a shot if you like the actors in it.

Fantastic and clever film. Easily rewatchable even years after first viewing. Although the humor is dark, it is hilarious and endlessly quotable. Another master stroke from Three Billboards and In Bruges director Martin McDanagh
One of my favorite movies.
I'd just like to point out that this film only has 4 stars and the movie Monster Trucks has 4.5, while I haven't seen the latter, this ratings discrepancy has made me a firm believer in eugenics.
Very entertaining, rather twisted at times, but good humor, quite a winding plot.  I really enjoy Christopher Walken movies - he is a great actor!
Ay, that's pretty good!

OMG, this was the film which led me to discover the greatness of the McDonagh brothers in writing dialog and coming up with wacky, hilarious, and scary plots managing to extract the best performances you've ever seen from participating actors like Christopher Walken and Colin Farrell and Sam Rockwell and Tom Waits.. Yes, a fluffy little dog is stolen from its gangster owner. Yes, the dude is practically in tears. Yes, you will laugh til you...have to go to the bathroom. Yes, you may learn to love this film as much as I do.
Entertaining and worth a watch!

I wanted to see this film because I loved Martin McDonagh's "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" and "In Bruges."  I'd somehow missed "Seven Psychopaths" when it came out - perhaps because the title was somewhat off-putting, lol.  McDonagh's writing is intelligent and witty, his characters and stories engaging, despite the dark emotions and violence.  "Psychopaths" is the lesser of the three films - not quite as good as the other two, but still worth seeing.  As with the other two films, there are unexpected turns and very funny moments.  Excellent cast and performances.
Good movie! The shock, twist and humor added volumes to this movie.
Fun & clever with fabulous characters.
A scream
You know what's coming for most of the movie, or do you? Awesome perspectives.
It's funny-ish. I liked it I may watch it again.

Three stars. I don't regret having watched it, but don't care to watch it again. There's a TON of really fun character actors in here, clearly having a great time. But it's one that's really only good for a single view.
It was so twisted I didn't see anything coming. The movie made use of all the expected cliches only they were turned on their heads. Make me another one.
everything fine

I can't help but wonder what people who rated this 1-star were expecting...  I guess a majority of Amazon customers do not have a grasp on what dark humor is, or just don't understand it?  Likely the same people who gave Ace Ventura 5-stars, but gave Cable Guy 1-star.

You also have to take Amazon reviews with a grain of salt, when you consider that Independence Day (worst movie ever made IMO) and Over the Top (a step up from 'stop or my mom will shoot') have 4.5 stars on Amazon... so there's that.

As for the movie...  people had a hard time following the script?  The characters are basically writing the movie throughout the movie, the 1-star people couldn't follow that?

Overall, worth a watch, and something to throw on if there's nothing else on.  Best movie ever?  No.  While I do like In Bruges a bit better, there are definitely much worse movies to watch on here as part of Amazon's "thousands of titles included with prime!!!"

Sam Rockwell is great in this... well, Sam Rockwell is great in everything, but his monologue of the "shootout" at the end is probably my favorite scene in the movie.  There's even one quick part where you can see Walken trying not to laugh.

Farrell is... Farrell.  I like him in this, and In Bruges.  Outside of that, it's the movies he picks that I don't like (Phone Booth is awful), not his acting.

Woody Harrelson is pretty funny in this as well, but I kinda wish they would've cast someone a bit more menacing as a mafia gangster type, unless that was on purpose?  Having Ralph Fiennes play the gangster role after his role as Harry in In Bruges would've been perfect.

The talented, award-winning Martin McDonagh shows little respect for his material or the audience. Thumbing his nose at the American public on this first Hollywood project he tries for a "Pulp Fiction" type film but with no coherence. And asking Carter Burwell to add soul to the film with some pastiche song bits shows desperation. Burwell's gone to the well too often. What happened to him since "Oh, Brother, Where Art Thou?" Stick with  McDonagh's first, "In Bruges" from 2008.

A lot of the reviews of this film seem to miss the point. Not that its too smart for some people, just thats definitely multi-layered. Seven Psychopaths attempts and succeeds at both parodying and homaging action films and the creative writing process. The main character is named for the writer and director of this film, showing the struggle for originality when it comes to action movies. With its dark comedy, complexly driven characters, and great acting, it delivers on all it sets out to. The crazy bloodbath action scenes aren't meant to copy Tarantino or to pander to young boys who love guns in film, but to make fun of the tropes of Hollywood. It homages Tarantino with its opening, because those are good and original action films, but then satirizes the lack of originality with the ideas pitched for the final climatic battle. Its layered, deep, yet funny enough to not take itself too seriously. I would recommend to fans of the film writing process or action films of any type.

I found myself constantly stopping the movie just to savor the many many moments. Part dark comedy, part Waiting for Godot. Your guess. Surely more depth of the bottomless well than all the Oscar winners. Good luck.

To me the story line was fresh and interesting and as some others noted it did turn on itself and the characters did wrestle with each of their own points of view and beliefs.

 Really, would you even know if you sat down in a cafe with one of these people, we are all just a simple decision away from being the good guy or the bad guy. Just watch it and enjoy it for what it is Entertainment.

3.5 Stars. I liked it. My wife not so much. It's basically your "budding writer-director cutting his teeth with his UCLA film school hitman/crime/Tarantino-esque first script" movie. Acting is fantastic. I'm a fan of everyone in this movie, especially Sam Rockwell.

Plot centers around a screenwriter/alcoholic (Colin Farrell) trying to write a script called 7 Psychopaths. His best friend, played by Rockwell, kidnaps dogs for a living, which leads everyone down the sewer hole when the wrong dog gets nicked from the wrong crime boss (Woody Harelson). Think Elmore Leonard and Get Shorty meet True Memoirs of an International Assassin with Kevin James. It's not a perfect analogy but the vehicle of the characters writing the movie you're actually watching fits, so does the reference to Elmore Leonard-type underworld characters.

Plenty of blood splatter and dark humor to go around. I didn't love it but I was glued to my TV.

Pretty good characters, fine acting, and a compelling pace keep this film moving in the right direction. There's a subtle nod and wink to the True Romance genre, as if, thankfully, the filmmakers and cast did not take it too seriously.

I think the screen writer had no real idea of what a psychopath is and could have benefited from some research.  Also, the music sequences are horrible.  Whoever the sound editor was must have lost quite a bit of hearing, because whenever a soundtrack was played I had to grab the remote and drop the volume down quite a bit.  I think professionals know how to match volumes and bring in music gently.  This marks it as an amateurish production despite a couple of good stars.  It was okay for killing some time, but not the kind of movie that is worth watching again.

Somewhat farcical creation, in which the screen writer manages to avoid most of the pitfalls inherent in being a writer, writing a righteous writer's story, while throwing together a bunch of grisly, darkly comic scenarios in a more or less logical fashion.  Mostly.  Give up your deep seated/seeded/ceded need to find real life characters to sort of represent what you'll find in this movie and you'll have a good time.  There's a fair amount of blood, but limited in duration.  Some very strange anti-heroes (all seven psychopaths) and one near realistic character at the periphery, collecting material for a movie.  Not as much fun as Get Shorty, and more of the writers-writing-writers issues, but different.  One I recommend seeing.

Seven Psychopaths is about some guy trying to write a script for a movie and his wacky friends trying to help him write his movie.  Wackiness and tragedy ensues.  All the female characters in the movie, Seven Psychopaths, have less than ten minutes screen time and die.  In one scene, one of the movie script writer's friend tells the writer, "Your script is terrible, all the female characters have less than ten minutes screen time and die!"  The writer's freinds talk about their ideas for a movie, so we have movies within a movie.  They talk about things they done so we have flashbacks.  The Movies within the movie and flashbacks make Seven Psychopaths unique.  In one flashback scene, the Zodiac Killer is depicted as an old hippie.  We all know Ted Cruz is the Zodiac Killer.

Seven Psychopaths is a clever and fun black comedy and a twisted take on the mind of the writer enduring writer's block. If you laughed about Marvin's head getting blown off in Pulp Fiction, let's just say that Seven Psychopaths has an even funnier head blowing off scene. That sounds horrible but hey, it's true.

Colin Farrell somehow manages to be lovable, Sam Rockwell (The Green Mile, Confessions of a Dangerous Mind) continues his brilliant streak playing charismatic psychos, Woody Harrelson is as menacing as ever and Christopher Walken gives a wonderfully subdued performance full of heart.

Seven Psychopaths is a particularly difficult film to enjoy, I feel. This is mostly due to the confusing ad campaign which made it seem like a wacky comedy, when it is so much more. Even then, this film may not be to everyone's liking, mostly because of the disjointed nature the plot and some of the more bizarre aspects. Even still, fans of film as a medium will enjoy it. The meta narrative woven throughout the plot, linking the protagonist's unfinished script and the plot of the film in such a way as to explore the genre of crime drama/action films and showing just how messed up the minds of characters in those films would actually have to be in order for the plot to actually happen. Yet it also pokes fun at the art house crowd as well, with Colin Farrell's pacifistic Marty's desire to write a life affirming film about psychopaths coming to a head with Sam Rockwell's more unhinged Billy and his more mainstream desire to make it an action film with gratuitous gore and sex so the film isn't boring. Peppered throughout, are some great moments both comedic and dramatic, with the always wonderful Christopher Walken stealing every scene he's in.

As a comedy, the film is rather short on laughs, but for fans of director Martin McDonagh's previous film "In Bruges" they will feel right at home with the subtle humor mixed in with surprisingly serious drama. Regardless, Seven Psychopaths proves to be a fun, mad, ride that is beautifully shot and edited and definitely worth a watch.
Spectacularly shot, excellent character development, and just an overall engaging story. Definitely a must watch, a dark one, but a must watch nonetheless.

I've seen it a few times, and familiarity does not breed contempt for this little film. If you despised 'In Bruges,' and its foul-mouthed mix of grit, absurdity, and tough-guy violence, you'll hate this, too. But, as a woman who loves tense action films, character-driven stories, originality, wit, and Christopher Walken, I love this!

Yes, the central character is an alcoholic writer whose problems are largely self-inflicted. Yes, he has a jackass best friend whose legal name ought to be Liability. Yes, where the aforementioned friend is concerned, the protagonist inhabits a moral vacuum. But, so much about Seven Psychopaths is fresh, self-assured, and joyous. This film is that one "weird" kid at school who didn't suck up to popular kids, didn't wear his 20 year-old hand-me-downs with shame; the kid whose potential went supernova because he wasted no effort placating people who never gave a damn about him anyway.

It's small, it's modestly appointed (few of these guys have money), and every actor wears his or her character like a bespoke suit. If, like me, you're always wondering how & why some pretty decent men sustain friendships with mad eejits, you'll grasp some of the appeal of this movie.

I should have known you were involved in another fave "In Bruges." I will heretofore etch your name into my brain.

This movie is not for those who are offended by curse words or violence or social/political incorrectness.

But then, the movie is called "Seven Psychopaths", isn't it? Shouldn't that suggest that the film probably wouldn't be enjoyed by those who are easily offended by such things? Those are the sorts of things psychopaths might be likely to indulge in...right?

Sadly, the content of most of the 1- and 2-star reviews seems to suggest that quite a few people didn't make that inference. "I stopped watching because of the repeated use of the f-word." "I couldn't continue watching after they called the one lady the n-word." Etc. etc... These are horrible people we're watching, folks. Of course they're going to offend us.

Oh well, I thought the movie was great. But I'm not about to be like so many other reviewers and list all of the plot details. Spoilers are no fun.

This is a dark comedy. It's certainly not meant to appeal to common sensibilities; most often it's meant to satirize them. It also (quite amusingly) satirizes itself and the general "gangster/revenge drama" genre which it very much knows it fits into (mostly). The movie laughs at itself, it's intentionally absurd at times, but if you stick around and pay attention the payoff is there to be enjoyed.

This is a great movie.  I don't know why some people feel compelled to write out the entire storyline in their reviews.  Its really more simple than that.  Is the movie entertaining and does it make you glad you watched it?  If yes, then good movie.  This one is.

I loved this. Many reviewers, however, did not - which is only to be expected, as this one is definitely not what it says on the tin. For some reason it was marketed as a comedy:  a Tarantino-esque, crime fiasco movie. And in the first half, it does have moments of masquerading as just such a movie. But if that's what you came for, you're likely to go away disappointed, because this is not that movie. It succeeds on that level, to a point. But only to a point. If what you want is a great beer drinking night movie full of wild scenes and crazy laughs, you're going to find the second half boring.

The second half is where the movie takes its mask off. Underneath is a different kind of movie entirely. A movie about a writer trying to understand what it means to be a psychopath, so he can finish his screenplay, who gets far more insight than he bargained for. You may hate that movie or you may love it. But that's the movie you're getting. It doesn't have the seven psychopaths pictured on the movie poster in it. And it's only incidentally about a kidnapped dog.

In my case, the real movie starts with three strikes against it:  1) I can't stand Colin Farrell, never forgiven him for his atrocious performance in Alexander. 2) I hate movies with main characters who are movie writers, they make me feel the writer was lazy and desperate. 3) I hate even worse the trope that writers can't write anything except exact depictions of events they personally live through so they have to live the events of the movie and then write about it. This is that movie.

And yet it works, for me at least. Your mileage may vary. There's a good case to be made that the goal is pretentious, that the second half drags, that the moral when it comes is about as subtle as a shovel to the side of the head. Several reviewers seem to feel that this is a failed parody of crime fiasco movies, which I think is missing the point. This not intended as a parody of anything. It's a deadly serious movie about crime fiasco movies, and what it would feel like to be friends with the people from them. There are some great laughs along the way, but the best bits are not the funny bits.

It goes without saying that this is a great cast. Christopher Walken walks off with every scene he's in. Woody Harrelson projects an aura of effortless menace. Sam Rockwell manages to be so disturbing that it's sometimes hard to look at him. I even liked Colin Farrell.

If black humor, cheese, buckets of gore, and overt philosophy lessons sound good to you, you might just love this movie. If not - at least you can't say I didn't warn you.

Seven Psychopaths is a much different comedy than most, in the sense that it has a special nostalgia that most action-comedies do not. The cast is absolutely perfect with great cameos (including Tom Waits). The film is about a screenwriter who is having trouble writing his next piece about seven psychopaths, each with their own story and special traits to make the story have it's own personality. Soon the screenwriter finds out his story may be more truth than fiction. This is a movie I simply can't suggest enough with it's slightly excessive violence and over the top comedic cast, it's really one worth checking out for any fan of gun-fights, comedy, and Woody Harrelson.

I was curious to see this after having very much enjoyed the director's previous film IN BRUGES, which also featured Colin Farrell. While both films share some similar thematic points or character qualities, SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS is a bit more meandering in terms of unfolding it story-line. It's one of those "Hollywood' set screwball comedies with a few graphic bursts of violence and craziness. Christopher Walken is very good in it, but his performance doesn't feel like much of a stretch for him. The character he played felt written for what we would expect him to act like anyway. Tom Waits has a fun cameo in it. He plays a variation on a Dexter like serial killer. I like the cast overall and it's (mostly) fun to hang out with them for the duration. Sam Rockwell is the crazy funny guy with Farrell acting mainly as the straight man here, Woody Harrelson is entertaining as a very angry mob guy who loves his little dog. It's a fun film but nowhere even close to as good as IN BRUGES which is just terrific IMO. Both films share a sense of humor that is very dark, but the earlier film delivers on the set-up in a way this one falls short of. If you enjoy movies set around L.A. withe a lot odd ball characters, and leavened with bits of over the top nastiness, you'll perhaps like this.

There may be a message of sorts, in this film about a  murderous psychopath bent on ridding society of other murderous psychopaths... or maybe not. All I know is, I enjoyed watching this dark comedy. Collin Farrell plays Marty, a screen writer struggling with a script about Seven Psychopaths. His drinking gets in the way of his writing, until his friend Billy (Sam Rockwell) offers to help. Things get out of hand when Billy and his friend Hans, played by Christopher Walken, kidnap the dog of a ruthless crime boss. The movie is populated by more than a few crazy characters and at times it is difficult to keep track of what is real and what exists only in the mind of any one of them. But the acting overcomes all of that. Walken is absolutely perfect, as always, just being himself. There is some nudity and a lot of violence.

First these guys aren't psychopaths they are sociopaths. A psychopath means that they have a mental disturbance and they would kill you because they think you're Frankenstein. A sociopath means they don't give a damn about societies rules and they shoot you for whatever damn reason they please.

Imagine Dalmer or Son of Sam as a contract killer; they couldn't put it together for 2 minutes. Those  guys are psychopaths.
Imagine a 4 star general going rogue (Apocalypse Now): those are sociopaths.

Titles and script should match.

A twisted, darkly humourous plot full of elaborate, back-story character profiles (with great casting), big budget action scenes, and enough thoughtful dialogue to keep the movie from becoming the caricature of itself. It all comes together almost seamlessly and keeps the story from being just another glitzy, Hollywood flick. This is not another yawn-inspiring film. There is a lovely magic to it.

Brilliant film -- who could want more than Colin Farrell, Christopher Walken, and a dog? If you liked In Bruges (or any of Martin McDonagh's works for the stage), you'll love Seven Psychopaths. Classic McDonagh storytelling (and dark humor coupled with brutality).
Like a Hunter Thompson tales, blurring lines between reality, fiction, this movie gives a very personal inside look into movie script writing.

Amazing movie, love every minute of it... contains almost every element you can think of: violence, philosophy, comedy, poignancy, action et al. The biggest surprise was the humor - I was expecting subtle ironic laughs, but this is genuinely historical - I mean fits of giggles funny - so many classic one-liners it needs a second viewing to catch them all. It's pretty much a male cast, and each is superb/flawless - Christopher Walken's character has spiritual power and a quirky stubbornness "put your hands up... no... why?... I don't want to... but I have a gun... yeah, I know" - Sam Rockwell is awesome as the goofball psycho, Woody Harrelson just has the mean, vicious, bad guy down so well now, but here he adds the comedy brilliantly: "my guns jammed again... you need to get a new one boss... but I like the blue handle" - Colin Farrell, pulls off the alcoholic, confused writer, (who is also the only character living on the edge of his nerves) perfectly - he wants to write a movie about a Buddhist, pacifist psychopath - so no wonder he's stuck - he toys with changing the main character to Amish or Quaker - he basically wants to write a gentle movie but is stuck with a great title "Seven Psychopaths" ... and it all flows from there. This movie has an absurdly crammed plot but never once does it lose itself or become incoherent - genius on the part of the writer/director - it's also evident that this is a British movie set in the USA, the way it handles itself is so NOT Hollywood - thankfully!!!!

Sam Rockwell and Christopher Walken were an absolute delight to watch in this violent, yet very heartwarming story of dog kidnappers, mobsters and (of course) psychopaths. This movie is quite original in its handling of the skewed line between reality and entertainment. Woody Harrelson and Colin Farrel are also quite entertaining, but are somewhat dimmed by the brilliance of Rockwell and Walken. I was also very excited to see Tom Waits with a small (yet very creepy) part in this fun film. I love him as an actor as much as I love him as a musical performer.

You know, I generally don't like this type of Christian based "formula" love story, but somehow, "Seven Psychopaths" is much different. It kind of writes itself. I felt very close to this story. Oh the pains of writing. Getting critiques and advice that ping pongs a screenplay around to the point of not recognizing the story anymore. But before I get into that, I think it is important for me to bring up two important things: Number 1- No animals were harmed in this film. The Shih-Tzu and the rabbits were handled very gingerly. That's not easy to do, what with all the shootings, stabbing, incineration, and explosions. And letter B- P.P. Arnold sounds a lot like Ronnie Spector. They played "The First Cut Is The Deepest" while the credits roll.  I used to tell my wife that I thought the words in the credits go down, when in actuality, they go up. It's my eyes that are going down as the words go up. If I ever finish a screenplay, I'm going to have the credits go down, instead of up. Sort of a break away from the Hollywood "rules". Maybe I'll have to try to get a deal in China to get agreement on that. Arghh, I'll never get finished, what with the subtitles and everything. Almost forgot- Roman Numeral III- Sam Rockwell would be great playing Johnny Carson in a movie. I noticed that in the movie "Everybody's Fine".  I can picture him saying "I did not know that." Hay yo-o-o-o-o! Look, I'm not going to say anything else about the movie. You have experience it. I will say this though... If you put Woody Harrelson and Christopher Walken in a movie together, it's not going to be your typical Christian based love story. And then stick Tom Waits in there for some extra weirdness. "got no time for the corner boys, down in the street makin' all that noise,  don't want no whores on eighth avenue, cause tonight i'm gonna be with you.  cause tonight i'm gonna take that ride, across the river to the jersey side,  take my baby to the carnival, and i'll take you on all the rides, sing sha la  la la la la sha la la la.  down the shore everything's alright, you with your baby on a saturday night,  don't you know that all my dreams come true, when i'm walkin' down the street  with you, sing sha la la la la la sha la la la..."

I was SO looking forward to watching this film.  For one thing, how can you go wrong with a cast like that?  But no, the writer/director just had to ruin it with over-the-top violence, gore, and language.  Too bad really; the premise and the screenplay were freaking brilliant.  I laughed almost constantly the first 10 minutes.  The comic relief wasn't enough to lift you over the disturbing stuff though. What could have been just enough violence to convey realism, turned in to a gore-fest about the joy of killing.  Something you'd expect if Quentin Tarantino collaborated on a movie with Charles Manson.  (Why did you have to go THERE, McDonagh?)  Seems like the actors would have said, "Hey!  Let's tone it down a little!"  I turned it off after 20 minutes or when I got nauseated - can't remember which happened first.

I gave it 3 stars for originality, clever dialogue, and several hilarious lines.  And for Sam Rockwell.  (Note to self:  Use caution next time you start to watch a Martin McDonagh film.)

Like Zero Effect, this is more likely than not one of the best under-rated films of the last two decades (though it doesn't quite reach the level of Fight Club or Donnie Darko...it may vie with Vanilla Sky or Before Sunrise). Primarily it rests on the merits of its writing...darkly humorous with an interesting, possibly psychological-literary-critic's mentality and a Looney Tunes playfulness when it comes to tying things together). And, if I had to guess, the cast came together for little more than peanuts, simply because they loved the screenplay.

If you liked any of the films I've listed, you could probably ignore the bad reviews this film has received. If you're sailing in that boat, watch it with an open mind, even if you can't stand Colin Farrell. S****...plenty of people hate Bill Pullman, Brad Pitt, Jake Gyllenhaal, Tom Cruise and Ethan Hawk, too...

Between the end of February 2015 and May 2015 I watched seven (7) movies, in addition to the 10 I previously contributed reviews for, where Colin Farrell played a key role.  In alphabetical order, the 7 movies are: Ask the Dust, Cassandras Dream, Horrible Bosses, Minority Report, The Recruit, Seven Psychopaths and Winters Tale.

I only now became aware that the actor was being honored for his overall achievements in film.  Around mid- May this year, the movie The Lobster was awarded third place (Prix du Jury) in the Cannas Film Festival, which an international award.  But, its the Maui Film Festival Navigator Award that sums up my sentiments of Colin Farrells performances in every movie I have watched so far. Theres nothing I could write that could be more persuasive to get people to watch his movies than recent recognition of the actor and his abilities.  It seems appropriate to  support the actor and the movies Ive watched by posting this in lieu of fleshing out individual reviews.

The following is from MauiNow.com (Posted 06:23 PM HST, June 5, 2015):
Colin Farrell was the recipient of the esteemed Navigator Award, during the Celestial Cinema on Friday night (06/05/2015) at the 16th annual Maui Film Festival.

The Maui Film Festival Navigator Award honors a film artist for carving a path of distinction through the turbulent waters of the entertainment industry without sacrificing their fundamental commitment to excellence.

Colin Farrell is a chameleon who constantly creates one-of-a-kind characters that send pitch perfect pebble-to-boulder-sized ripples through whatever story his performance is helping to tell, said festival founder and director Barry Rivers. In short, Colin is a cinematic force of nature and, for that reason, the Maui Film Festival takes great pride in honoring him with its 2015 Navigator Award.

Any movie with Christopher Walken is worth watching and this is no exception. It's fun, interesting and fast paced and definitely off the reservation in terms of story line. The overall concept is that you're following an author while he struggles with his sobriety to write another book. He has a crazy friend that inspires him to write his crazy next novel. Another crazy friend (Walken) that kidnaps dogs for ransom. All the while, the author, crazy friend and Walken are being chased by Woody Harrelson as he tries to save his kidnapped dog. Woody Harrleson is a mafia sort of fella with no real empathy except for his missing pocket pet dog. You have to have an open mind, be willing to embrace the crazy, and not really mind that the story is all over the place while interjecting dry wit humor. If you can do that, you'll enjoy this ride!

As you can probably see, this movie is not for everyone.  This is a comedy that requires a good amount of attention to fully grasp, and you'll need to have a decent amount of appreciation for the unexpected and the ridiculous.  A good measure to tell if you'd like this movie is if you like It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia (more specifically the bar critic episode).  The characters try to solve their problems in the worst possible ways; if you think that is funny, you'll love this movie.  To me, it is a great refresher from the tired-out Seth Rogen, Todd Phillips, and Scot Armstrong brand of comedy, which seem to be the only style coming out.

A DELIGHTFULLY DARK BON-BON laced with vivid splashes of blood, some gore and lots of pyrotechnics ...

ROCKWELL, FARRELL, WALKEN, HARRELSON, WAITS STANTION plus a delightful little poochie all layer this dark tale set in Hollywood, dealing with writer's block - is it?  Our writer - the devilishly handsome Mr. Farrell - an Irish Laddie who likes his wee drop of whiskey  - literally finds himself surrounded by 'the afflicted' including his Actor friend - the always delightful Mr. Rockwell who plays an out of work Actor with rather an unusual side-job.

From the opending scene which introduces us to two patiently waiting hit men - to the concluding 'shots' one just cannot look away.  The desert sequences are particularly beautiful.

It's something along the lines of "Black Marble" meets "A Fish Called Wanda" ..... and fragments of a classic Pekinpah blood-bath throughout - when 'things' run foul.

Tech credits are solid - highly recommended.

Extremely well written dialogue and terrific performances by Sam Rockwell, Colin Farrell, Woody Harrelson and last but not least Christopher Walken made this movie thoroughly entertaining.

Instead, it is a farce that illustrates an ideal about human existence and hope. I love this movie, and hope to see more like it in the future.

I am not sure what the person who originally wrote this movie intended it to be when it was written, but the end result was scattered everywhere, and didn't make a lot of sense.  One character seemed normal and then all of sudden murdered someone for no reason.  There were also secondary characters thrown in that were not needed, and were just unsuccessful attempts at some comic relief, and then once you think you figured out a character they changed and not in a good way.  This was supposed to be a dark comedy, but I did not think it was funny at all.  Not even Woody Harrelsons weird obsession with his Shiz Tzu made me laugh.  I am glad that Colin Farrell finally found his niche in comedy but this is a movie he should have passed on.  Not even Christopher Walken could make this movie funny.  I am sure that there will be some people who disagree with me and that is fine, but I bought this movie based on positive reviews and felt obligated to do one of my own after watching it.

Gleefully dark comedy with a habitual tendency to go meta. That's actually a central point of the plot, which revolves around Colin Farrell's tail-chasing efforts to compose the film's screenplay whilst in the midst of it. We dance around this issue for a bit in the first hour, but once embraced it leads to a number of sharp, bitterly funny conversations and revelations that really help the film stand out as something different. Its jaded, desensitized approach to gruesome violence can be unsettling, but something tells me that's kind of the point. For that matter, so are the simple, shallow characters that pepper the perimeter and the story's rambling, uncertain climax. Farrell is constantly bookended by his cohorts, Sam Rockwell and Christopher Walken, who portray two glaringly colorful characters but don't really bring a lot of depth or flavor to the mix. They're each painted with a single stroke, which could again be construed as part of the film's message... but at some point it's natural to question how many times it can fall back on that ready-made excuse. Funny, black hearted and world-weary, but it feels like too much attention is paid to the undercurrents in lieu of the ocean.
Depth hidden within layers of plot and hilarious comedy. Enjoyed everything from the cast to the writing. Really great movie.
- Definitely worth the buy it's a great buy with tons of action and cute dogs to boot. It's not for the faint of heart but it's a great ride.

You're left wishing you could regain those wasted hours of your life, and consoling yourself with the thought that the actors must feel 100 times worse for the time they invested in this horrible movie.  Oh wait... at least they got paid. By suckers like you.

My main complaint is that the movie is so, so serious and psycological, no pun intended, but it is a lot more depressing than the previews came across. It's like a comedy version of Taxi Driver. You have these actors going through the ins and outs of being a psychopath on screen and doing crazy crap, and that's just not what the preview made the movie come across as. Yes, there was supposed to be general insaneness and killing--but there's really no main comedy tone, it's mostly a sad depressing tone about the varying levels of being a psychopath and what the psychopaths want from their drama to fulfill their psychopathic desires. That would be the main theme of the movie, how each psycho feels about their drama and what they want from the drama they hope to create in their lives.

I thought it was a little disgusting there was so much violence against women in this movie. That's where I really regretted renting it. There was real drama against women, there was a lot of it, there were fantasies about it, and at that point, despite being able to get through the nasty sex scenes, the crazy, violent, and grotesque for anyone's standards, murders, (and by anyone's standards that is not a joke because I had some pretty twisted English professors in college who made AN ALL GIRLS DETECTIVE NOVEL CLASS read super-duper sick rape literature) it just became a little too heavy, and I would not rent the movie again. I personally hate the Godfather movies because there is so much crazy, arbitrary, gross, and unnecessary raging, violence, and revenge against women....and I think that's only entertaining for psycopathic, psycopathetic males. End of story. It's too bad the great acting could have been more enjoyable with a less weird tone and sexist script writing.

This is an okay flick to watch once, and there's really no reason to buy on Blu Ray since there are hardly any special effects.  The story is weak, cliche and just not what I expected at all. I nearly turned it off...it it weren't for Walken...and even he didn't come to the film's rescue.

Honestly? Hmmm... very mixed feelings about this.

Screenwriter Marty (a subdued Colin Farrell who leaves most of the acting to his eyebrows) is suffering a creative block, when his best friend Billy (Sam Rockwell) gets him involved with a long term dog kidnapping caper that goes wrong when his partner ( Christopher Walken) inadvertently steals the mutt of the local mob boss (Woody Harrelson). Cue revenge, cycles of violence, road trips, guns... and Marty finding something to write about.

The opening sequence of this film is excellent, with shades of Quentin Tarantino's Pulp Fiction as a near-mythical vigilante dispatches two mob goons in a way that would have made Keyser Soze proud.

The problem is that it is downhill from there on. It is difficult to feel any sympathy for the main hero as he is an abusive alcoholic. His best friend is a psychopath who has no hesitation in dispatching innocent women.

The nearest character I came to liking was the Walken's morally bankrupt dog thief.

It is interesting to note that the film is its own harshest critic when, about two-thirds of the way through, Marty presents a draft script to his pals based on events so far, and they tear it apart for being one-dimensional, lacking any decent female characters and sloppy dialogue. It also gives away the ending at that point too, which I found disappointing.

Was this entertaining? To a degree, yes... but I wouldn't watch it again.

It's quite violent and it deals with a dark side of humanity, but this film handles it well.  It's what makes a movie watchable or a book readable: dark, scary, weird things, when handled correctly, can and should spur people on to think critically.

But when my mother-in-law watched it and told us how good it was, we decided to take the plunge and watched it on a Saturday afternoon.

We're very glad we did.  Yes, there is graphic violence.  But, as odd as this sounds, it's not particularly disturbing as it is really necessary to advance the film.  The fact that humor is liberally distributed throughout the film makes it quite palatable.

All in all, it's a fun, albeit violent movie with great performances and good storytelling from start to finish.  It's well worth watching (of course, viewer discretion is advised because there *is* a lot of blood).

Writer/director Martin McDonagh (`In Bruges') has done it again - created a comedy out of a tale about killing. He pulls this off with a smart script and with a cast of actors that simply could not be improved upon. Once it starts it doesn't stop  - not even at the end of the film when the absurdities just keep flying.

Chronically drunk Irish screenwriter Martin (Colin Farrell) has serious writer's block to the point that his drunken diatribes result in the loss of his girl Kaya (Abbie Cornish) and draws him closer to his best friend and wannabe writer Billy (Sam Rockwell - never better and in fact the true star of this film!). Martin is struggling to write a screenplay called `Seven Psychopaths' and Billy helps him find the characters to reference: crazy old bunny carrying Zachariah (Tom Waits) who shares his youthful killing spree with his wife (Amanda Warren), Cop Charlie (Woody Harrelson) and his sidekick Paulo (Zeljko Ivanek) out looking for Charlie's kidnapped Shih Tzu blamed on an innocent Sharice (Gabourey Sidibe), but actually dognapped by Hans (Christopher Waken) to support his hospitalized wife (Linda Bright Clay - in a terrific cameo), a strange old man (Harry Dean Stanton) who slices his own throat, a loony Vietnamese priest (Long Nguyen) and other equally psychopathic characters. There is bona fide madness within and without every character and the manner in which McDonagh makes it all play out is a feat of cinematic genius. In the end Martin realizes that madness is reality and finishes his film  - with a severe twist at the end.

Carter Burwell is responsible for the imaginative musical score, even borrowing a supply gorgeous passage, 'Premiers transports que nui n'oblie' from Berlioz' Romo et Juliette performed by The Monteverdi Choir & Orchestre Rvolutionnaire et Romantique with Catherine Robbin, Jean-Paul Fouchcourt & John Eliot Gardiner (for those curious as to which recording was borrowed!). Every aspect of this crazy, zany, madcap, hilarious adventure somehow works. Comedy is king in McDonagh's hands. Grady Harp, December 13
this is one for those of you who like the type of movies that Woody Harrelson and Christopher Walkin tend to do kind of dark 'comedy'.  It's great, if you enjoy those kinds of films.

This is a lunatic movie.  It's sad and funny and absolutely crazy.  The script is good, the acting is good and the music is good.  Warning:  there's plenty of violence.

Marty (Colin Farrell) is a Hollywood writer having a writers block (and a drinking problem, too) trying desperately to come up with an idea for the next project titled Seven Psychopaths. The idea arrives in an unexpected way when his officious friend Billy (Sam Rockwell) steals a dog that happened to be a sadistic gangsters.

Though set in Hollywood, Seven Psychopaths is a British crime comedy with a great cast including Christopher Walken, Woody Harrelson and Tom Waits, as well as interesting cameos from Michael Pitt, Gabourey Sidibe and Harry Dean Stanton. This is a sophomore work of Martin McDonagh (In Bruges) as a feature director, which means something for avid filmgoers. The film is often very violent.

Not that I take issue with that. The problem is, despite the effective dark humor, Seven Psychopaths relies too much on violence to further the story, which goes nowhere in the second half. The film often looks like an assortment of discarded ideas for films that did not materialize. The characters self-referential remarks (about female characters, for instance) sound more like an excuse than humor.

The best thing of the interesting but overlong film is naturally Christopher Walken and his character Hans, a person with a dark and mysterious background. His back story alone, the most thought-out and intriguing one among others, is worth watching. On the contrary, female characters played by Abbie Cornish and Olga Kurylenko are little better than cyphers, or worse.

And writer / director Martin McDonagh obviously knows that, as thats exactly what one character in the film points out. This is where smugness gets the film, which stops being what it started out to be, a crime drama about seven psychopaths. Instead, it ends up being a commentary about itself, which is not really smart or interesting as it seems to think.
Great Rainy day Movie.......! Six Pack and a Pizza ! then another Six Pack....then another pizza. Have a nice day !

Kept waiting for it to get better. It never did and if anything got worse.  I wouldn't recommend it to an enemy.  Or Psychopath.  No plot worth watching. We could only watch the first 30 minutes before giving up - especially as the over use of the 'f' word was grating on my nerves.  Waste of money to amazon for this one.
It is a strange, dark movie. If you are in to that sort of thing, then this may be a good movie for you.

First off, if you don't like dark comedies, or if you can't stomach "self-aware" movies... then just don't watch.

But if you can get past that, then... omg, it's awesome.  All of these actors are at their best.  It's like all of Harrelson, Rockwell, and Walken were told to act as over the top weird/semi-psycho as they could.  Meanwhile, Farrell, the drunk, is the only sane one among the lot.

I think they all had their own moments and some really good lines.  My favorite line: "Friends don't make friends die for them!"  "Well, psychopathic friends do."

I watched it twice.  The second time around, I bought in HD because this is the kind of movie I could watch several times.

I don't want to ruin the movie, but you'll quickly realize all seven of the psychopaths are sort of anti-heroes or anti-psychos.

This movie was fantastic. It was so meta but it did that so well. It's never what you expect is gonna happen and it make you laugh and it makes you sad and, best of all, it makes you think. I've read a lot of the negative reviews here and you really shouldn't listen to any of them if you have half a brain. Odds are they went into this expecting a shoot-em-up formulaic action flick. What they got was so much better, but they didn't understand the message of the film, so they didn't get that. My advice: Go into this with no expectations, because if you're in the right mindset, it will blow your mind!

I'm not going to go into detail re: the plot because others have already done so.  Basically Collin Farrell somewhat of a drunk working on a screenplay and eventually his crazy friend (Sam Rockwell) starts to help and then Christopher Walken gets involved.  Along the way Woody Harrelson plays a bad guy out to get his dog back.  Mayhem ensues.

This film is funny in places, brutal in places and always interesting.  It's structured in a "meta" way at times, in that the screenplay becomes this movie, and they may talk through a scene and change it, and it will happen.

Overall it's not perfect - it's a little slow here and there and not everything makes sense - but the performances are just great.  Christopher Walken is always great, Collin Farrell is good (I generally like him but he's a bit overshadowed by the other performances here), Sam Rockwell is his usual quirky, excellent self (really, a truly underrated actor) and Woody Harrelson takes a criminal madman and makes him somewhat sympathetic.

This movie owes some style to Tarrantino, but still it's very enjoyable.  I'd say this is a quirky, interesting film that people will either love or hate.  If the performances weren't so good I don't think this movie would've worked.  But I like it a lot.

The cast is excellent, all at their funniest, especially Sam Rockwell (whose facial expressions are to die for!).

And, surprisingly, it had some insight and thoughtfulness to it for a comedy.
