This is a movie about making a movie--or that's what it pretends to be.

Theoretically, it's about Martin (Colin Farrell), who wants to write a screenplay called "Seven Pyschopaths," but who doesn't know anything about psychopaths and who hates violence--which is what psychopaths are all about.  So he's stuck.

But his friends, Hans (Christopher Walken), and Billy (Sam Rockwell), help him out.  Hans and Billy support themselves by dog-kidnapping, a low-level scam that sometimes nets them effusive rewards from the grateful owners.  (They don't threaten; just keep the dogs a couple of days silently, then return them as "found.")

Both Hans and Billy turn out to be nutcases in their own way, and both help Martin develop his psychopath stories.  Billy points out a newspaper story about a mysterious, masked Jack of Diamonds killer who only kills mafia hitmen.  A serial-killer killer.

Billy also places a personal ad for psychopaths in a little freebie paper, which turns up Tom Waits.  Waits carries around a white rabbit, and tells his strange history of rescuing a young woman decades ago who had been captured by a serial killer.  He and she kill the killer and then go on a long campaign of killing serial killers, including, among others, the Zodiac.  Another pair of serial-killer killers.

Hans connects up with another psychopath-story, about a Quaker whose daughter is murdered by a psychopath.  The murderer is caught and jailed, but the Quaker forms a vendetta and pursues him--into jail and beyond, even though the killer has reformed.  Hans apparently is the Quaker.  Hans also resolves Martin's Vengeful-Vietnamese-Priest story relatively peacefully.

Hans and Billy's dog-napping enterprise goes seriously awry when Billy dognaps the Shih-Tsu of a mafia general (Woody Harrelson).

Billy wants to have a big shootout with the mafia men, but Hans is a pacifist and Martin hates violence, so they drive out to the desert to mull it over.

Oh, and by the way, without spoiling anything, Billy is seriously and deeply and crazily misogynist.

It all ends strangely with Martin and Hans and Billy each getting what he wants.

There's a shocking amount of gore and a lot of meditation on whether violence can ever be used against violence.

And Billy, who is the only genuine psychopath, steals the show.

Sam Rockwell and Christopher Walken and Woody Harrelson are terrific, and so are all the women actors, though they have small-to-middling parts.  Colin Farrell is only so-so.  I have a feeling Colin Farrell can act, but mostly he doesn't bother to.

Fiction meets reality in this seriously dark comedy. Colin Farrell plays Marty, a struggling writer whose newest screenplay is based on select events in his life. The story involves several killers (thus the title) and how their lives become entangled in one another. Marty's concept is supplied to him by his friend and some time room mate Billy (Sam Rockwell).

Things are set in motion with Billy and Marty's other friend Hans (Christopher Walken), Billy's partner. These two are low level bad guys who make a living by kidnapping dogs of wealthy people and then returning them for a reward. Unfortunately the Shih Tzu that the pair of kidnapped at the moment is the beloved pet of big time mobster Charlie (Woody Harrelson) who sends out his minions to discover who would be so bold and to then kill them.

But the movie offers us more than just this simple story as Billy tells tale after tale to Marty about the various killers he's brought up. One is a Vietnamese killer out to set things straight. Another is a killer who feels his daughter was wronged by a young man. One is known as the Jack of Diamonds killer because he leaves a playing card behind on each of the high level mobsters he kills. And then there is Zachariah (Tom Waites) who replies to an ad Billy placed asking for psychopaths to tell Marty their story. Apparently Zachariah and his wife were multiple serial killers as he unfolds his tale to Marty only to then let him know he'll have to kill him eventually. All of these items play into the whole story that is not only being written by Marty but that he and his friends are actually living.

Along the way we also find out more about Hans and Billy. Hans' wife is in a nursing home and he visits her frequently. One of the many stories that Marty hears and writes about involves Hans and his wife. Several relate to Billy in one way or another. All have surprising consequences that you don't quite see coming as the story unfolds.

That's what makes this movie so special. The pieces of the puzzle are offered to you as viewer but they eventually drop into place as more and more are told the pieces turned this way and that as to make sense. About 2/3 into the film Marty, Hans and Billy go on a road trip to the desert and overnight more tales are told and almost everything the stories have led up to happens.

So many films these days love to take on the title of quirky and few ever live up to that concept. This film grasps it with both hands and clings to it tightly, deservedly so. It not only offers something truly different than most movies have to offer it does so with a unique blend of sadness, adventure and dark humor that rarely combine well but here come together like few films do.

There is nothing that is sub-par about anything involved in this film. The acting is tremendous and all three main leads have their moment in the sun. Farrell downplays his character so as to not be the leading man we've grown accustomed to. Rockwell shows that his abilities are almost always underused until now. And Walken at times does a parody of what we've come to associate with him but then shows that his character is perhaps the one with the biggest heart of all.

With a title like this some will shy away and be afraid of what they will encounter. Then again with the dark humor involved it might not be for everyone. But if you're willing to take a chance you'll find one of the funniest and most touching films albeit a gory film that you will find something to like in it. For me it's one to keep on the shelf and pull out from time to time to enjoy.
very bizarre but very entertaining.  The actors do a great job in this movie.  I would definitely recommend seeing it.

I have seen a number of reviews about this movie where people didn't quite seem to get the concept of it.  I'm not sure how the story got lost on them, but bravo for them for not getting the very simple story going on.  Needless action or gore?  Absolutely not.  Marty (Colin) is writing about psychopaths, both fictional and non-fictional.  Being as they are killers, this to me already said it was going to have a bit of gore.  It wasn't needless.  I'm sorry but comparing this to Tarantino and throwing in lines about needless things in movies...  I loved it.  The foundation for it all is really the relationship between Marty and Billy (Rockwell).  This movie kept me on my toes, loved it beginning to end.  Unlike most action movies, it does have some well done drama nearer to the end that ties it all together.  If you are looking for nothing but non-stop action, this may not be for you, but if you are up for an adventure and a good time, you should give this movie a watch.

The first time I watched this movie it was pretty funny.  As usual I watched it again and started wondering ... I asked friends, they had the same questions. We all watched it AGAIN, though it remains humorous each time - you can "over-think" this one and start asking if there really are SEVEN psychopaths ... or are YOU the psychopath? It's enjoyable, you will laugh, each actor was great in their role. Woody Harrelson always does a good psycho but this one is funny as well. Christopher Walken seemed to pull all his character types out here- except for the dancer. Colin Farrell's facial expressions should not be missed. I've only seen Sam Rockwell in a couple films so I can't say more than he plays his role well, too. I think there is something to like in this movie for almost anyone. There are a few things you will be left unsure of, if you see beyond the comedy.  Very good movie ... all I can say without making this review a spoiler.

Note: May contain spoilers. Proceed with caution.

A struggling writer, a stolen dog, and a group of crazy people. Does that sound like an interesting film to you? If not, then get out now. If so, then read on my friend because you just might be crazy enough to enjoy the insanity that is Seven Psychopaths. Crazy, over-the-top premise aside I found myself loving this film. It's fun, it's crazy, and it doesn't take itself too seriously.

You follow Marty Faranan (Colin Farrell), a struggling writer trying to finish his screenplay, "Seven Psychopaths". The problem is that Marty can't seem to get started and to top it off he has a bit of a drinking problem. As his friend Billy Bickle (Sam Rockwell) says, "It's in your f***ing blood, man!" Oh, Marty's Irish. So that's what Billy meant by "It's in your blood". Anyway, Billy is an unemployed actor who makes a living off of kid-napping dogs with his friend Has Kieslowski (Christopher Walken).

Things take a sharp turn when Billy steals a dog from a violent gangster by the name of Charlie Costello (Woody Harrelson). So now these three men are trying to run for their lives so as not to get their heads blown off by Charlie. In an attempt to get away they go out to the dessert where Marty continues to work on his screenplay with Billy and Hans. Only now, he's not sure that this thrilling psychopath movie is what he wants to write anymore because he wants the ending to be grounded and humane.

I never watched Martin McDonagh's previous film In Burges so I'm not sure how that compares to Seven Psychopaths, but if I had to compare this to another movie I think I would use Snatch. Now this is nowhere near the brilliance of Snatch, but Seven Psychopaths has some of the same elements. There's a lot of dark humor and the violence is so over-the-top that the would-be gruesome scenes come off as funny and comedic. Plus, the movie is filled with a lot of interesting characters.

What this film does extremely well, aside from providing you with a unique, engaging story, is keep you guessing. As Marty is writing his story he's starting to use real stories based on previous and current psychopaths (In the movie's world, not reality). So as you watch the story progress you get to see all seven psychopaths in the flesh. The twist is that a few of the characters in this movie appear relatively normal, but you soon learn that sometimes the normal ones are the craziest of them all.

I think that's why I enjoyed this movie as much as I did. You don't expect it to pan out the way that it does, but as you learn these secrets everything just feels right. There have been many recent movies that force these character twists and they don't feel natural, but Seven Psychopaths nails it with ease. It's one of those things that you don't see until you actually see it and then you go "Ohhhh".

Surprisingly, Seven Psychopaths isn't all laughs and violence. Throughout the movie you'll see Marty grow as an individual and there's a few heartfelt moments with Hans and his wife Myra (Linda Bright Clay). It's these moments that really help balance out the story and keep everything grounded. Even when Billy's having a shootout or Marty's getting drunk, life never stops. Things happen that are not always under our control. It adds a touch of heart and normality to an otherwise crazy experience.

Finally, the casting in this film is excellent and each of the four leads are phenomenal. Colin Farrell, Sam Rockwell, and Christopher Walken have fantastic chemistry on screen and it's a joy to watch them in a scene together. Then Woody Harrelson gave another one of his bad-boy-that-has-a-heart performances and nails it yet again. There's really not anyone to complain about in here because even the minor cast members like Tom Waits and Linda Bright Clay nailed their performances.

Overall Score: 8.25/10 - Seven Psychopaths is a blast from start to finish and I'm glad I finally got the chance to see it. It's funny and over-the-top, but it's also charming and there's enough heart there to keep the experience grounded. If you were eyeing this movie in theaters but didn't get the chance to see it then now's the time.

What can I say about this movie? It is weird, it is enjoyable, it is well acted, it makes NO sense for much of its running time, but by the end everything closes well and it has been well worth the journey.

Colin Farrell does some of his best acting here, Sam Rockwell is great as usual though you want to punch his character in the face every in other scene, and ONLY Christopher Walken can tell someone that he doesn't care that he's about to get shot and actually make you believe it. This movie is inventive, breaks from the typical structures, and is funny in a very dark way.

That's another thing. The marketing for this movie makes it seem laugh out loud funny and it is, BUT make no mistake, this is a DARK comedy. It is disturbing and harsh and though you will laugh, you will also cringe. Good movie and well worth a look for those who can handle the subject matter.

A movie that is amazing as the concept is bizarre. Seven Psychopaths is well made, full of action, and absolutely hilarious.

Marty (Colin Farrell) is an alcoholic screen writer with a terrible case of writers block. Martys friend Billy (Sam Rockwell) is very encouraging and constantly tries to help Marty with his screen play. It is clear that Marty doesnt respect Billy, and seeing the strange things Billy does, it is not all that surprising. Billy hangs out with a man named Hans (Christopher Walken). The two abduct dogs and hang on to them until the owners offer a reward. They then turn up and act innocent while returning the dog to collect the reward. Their relatively harmless plan takes a dark turn when Billy kidnaps Bonny, the shih tzu owned by a mob boss named Charlie (Woody Harrelson). The movie never stops moving and it moves quickly at that. Keeping up this pace for two hours is a huge credit to director Martin McDonagh. As the story unfolds it is told not only in the world of Marty, Billy, Hans, and Charlie but also in Martys head as he works his way through the screen play he is working on. As Martys situation becomes more chaotic the barrier between the two worlds starts to seriously blur.

Colin Farrell doesnt always make a hit but he is an actor who always tries hard. In this case his persistent hard work absolutely pays off since Psychopaths is an amazing movie. Farrell also stared in Martin McDonaghs previous movie In Bruges (also a 5/5). Farrell isn't quite the audience perspective or voice of reason in Psychopaths but he is the closest tether to reality the audience is given as they try to keep up with the insane actions of the rest of the movies characters. Sam Rockwell is the most far-out character by far. Despite Rockwells outrageous actions and ideas he is never guilty of chewing the scenery. He pushes his character to the limits but keeps control just enough to be amazing. Rockwell steals every scene he is in and proves yet again he is an actor who can handle any script that is given to him. Christopher Walken also delivers an impressive performance. It seems in recent years that Walken had essentially become a parody of himself and showed up in a lot of really terrible movies just so idiot teenagers would laugh at his distinct speech pattern. Walken is anything but a joke in Psychopaths. He is also out of the norm but at the same time a very calculated man who things about his actions and what he says, Walken gets some of the most shudder-ingly impressive scenes in the movie. Woody Harrelson is always a fan favorite despite most of his performances being very middle of the road. He never disappoints but never blows the audience away. Harrelsons role in psychopaths is a good one and definitely plays to Harrelsons strengths.

The script deserves a lot of credit for all the characters in the movie, it is clear they weren't created by the actors but the actors certainly brought them to life. With a lesser cast and crew this script, while obviously very strong, could have been pushed into the realm of far too ridiculous and fell flat on its face. The serious subject matter, brutal violence, and perfect blend of comedy are all proof of how strong the screen play really was.

Seven Psychopaths is a rare combination of fairly serious subject matter and outright hilarious comedy. The jokes are smart, the dialogue snaps, and the actors are flawless. Martin McDonagh took an incredibly strong script and molded it into an absolute master piece.

Seven Psychopaths isn't so much a movie about seven psychopaths as it is a movie about a movie about seven psychopaths. That is if merely being a brutal murderer qualifies a person as such. I'd argue that, outside of the pop-based pseudoscience known as psychology, it doesn't, but that semantic debate is beside the point. Director Martin McDonagh reels you in right from the beginning with two mob-style killers engaging in interesting dialogue,  la Quentin Tarantino, and the movie never really goes boring from there. It never really goes particularly enjoyable neither, let alone as clever as it aims to be. The Billy Bickle character, a source of comic relief in a movie that would do better without it, is annoying, but the little Shih Tzu dog, which plays a major role in relation to the plot, is adorable.

Like Quentin Tarantino and Guy Ritchie before him, Martin McDonagh has struck it rich with a crime caper formula that is witty, exciting, so unpretentious. He is a playwright by trade, and Seven Psychopaths is like watching a Broadway theatrical production on the big screen. The movie is very deja-vuish like U Turn, but is intelligent enough through its multi-layered storyline to top Inception. In most cases, when a director makes a movie about "making a movie" or an author writes about a "writer," it comes off as cliche and effective as beating a dead horse. I'm thinking latter day Steven King, especially the Z-grade movie adaptations that get churned out every other year. These types of movies/books/stories, etc. are stale before they hit the audience because the person at the helm is starving for original material and has nothing but their narrow-minded pursuit to draw upon. Seven Psychopaths rips on the entire movie industry, the acting profession, and the very core of celluloid as an art form while keeping its over-the-top action vehicle from derailing. The chemistry between a trio of Hollywood degenerates portrays irrational characters in a way that would not occur outside of a movie script (think Pulp Fiction), yet is dumb-downed enough for mass consumption. Collin Farrel and Sam Rockwell share leads, while Christopher Walken and Woody Harrelson play a good supporting cast. A shih-tzu is both central conflict and comedic sidekick. There is some excellent scenery chewing going on in this movie, and Christopher Walken delivers his finest performance in years at the end of the film. Yes, it can be mean-spirited at times, and I wouldn't consider Seven Psychopaths much of a comedy, but satire and a kickass movie experience it will deliver.

I'm a huge fan of `In Bruges'.  I thought it was a clever mix of action, thrills, comedy and emotional connection, and it provided Colin Farrell with his finest performance (and character) to date.  `Seven Psychopaths' was Martin McDonagh's follow up to `In Bruges', and with a reteaming with Farrell I must say that I was very interested (and hopeful) to see how this one panned out.

While not as well rounded as `In Bruges', `Seven Psychopaths' sports a rich ensemble cast and some fun dialog that keeps the scenes moving, even when the plot begins to ware thing.  The opening scene is brilliantly written and sets a tone for the film that made me anxious to see more.  Sadly, I found the floundering finale to be a bit of a letdown, and the overall development of the dual storylines (the actual psychos and the fictional tale regarding them) was somewhat gargled in the process.

That said, this is thoroughly entertaining!

The ensemble is pretty great, with Woody Harrelson taking the cake for me.  His brooding mix of theatrical emotions and commanding intensity made for an irresistible character.  The world loves Sam Rockwell far more than I do, and I've seen him play this character before, but he was funny and effective to say the least.  Walkin was Walkin, but the more tender moments felt really authentic.  Farrell is more of an observer here.  He's the least eccentric in the cast and so his character comes off slightly boring.  That isn't to say that he's bad here, he's just not the center of attention.

Funny, sharp and exciting, `Seven Psychopaths' may be as cluttered as the title suggests (and not as clear and concise as it should have been) but McDonagh has a knack for dialog and he makes the best of it here.

This movie was made by the Director/Writer of 'In Bruges' and it definitely shows - with a tie-in of familiar action, quirkiness, and even some faces. The movie has a Quentin Tarantino feel with its action, fast-paced motion of character progression, and dialogue-heavy conversations of a witty nature. The movie is also star-studded with big names showing up every which way, and in surprisingly small (and large) roles. Christopher Walken, as usual, steals the show with his stupendous acting that could crush the world with its might.

All-in-all, the movie isn't going to win best picture - but it's action packed, hilarious, and acted well and just down-right FUN. If you enjoy True Romance, In Bruges, the Way of the Gun, or Pulp Fiction - this movie might be worth a watch for you. Check it out!

The movie feels like several key elements relating to story and motivation were dropped, or just forgotten to be put in. So many things unanswered or just slid in - too many to go into here, too many plot holes and questionable motivations. It's too easy to excuse everyone's over-the-top behavior as being because "they are psychopaths" - it's a easy out - but the whole thing just feels half-baked to me.

The concept for a good film is here, vaguely, but unfortunately the vision of its premise is never realized.  The dialogue lacks the style and content to carry the story, which is itself quite weak, and the characters are too thinly imagined for the actors to ever bring to life.

In short: imagine in combination the violence of Tarantino without the crisp, witty dialogue; the pacing of In Bruges without the insight or the beauty; and the agony of knowing that you will never recover the time you've spent watching this movie.

Alternatively, you might consider watching reruns of old infomercials, and save yourself a few dollars.

From British filmmaker Martin McDonagh ("In Bruges", "Six Shooter") comes the black comedy film "Seven Psychopaths".  Premiering at the Toronto International Film Festival in Sept. 2012 and released in theaters the following month, "Seven Psychopaths" will now be released on DVD in Jan. 2013.

The film begins with a writer named Marty Faranan (portrayed by Colin Farrell), who is working on a screenplay titled "Seven Psychopaths", about seven psychopaths but for now, all he can think of is one.  A Vietnamese victim who wants revenge on the US military that killed his family during the Vietnam War.  And wanting to create an action-film, he's have a difficulty coming up with ideas.

Meanwhile, his friends include Billy Bickle (portrayed by Sam Rockwell), an unemployed actor and a crazy guy who steals dogs for a living in order to get owners cash rewards for the dog's safe return.  Billy tries to help Marty by trying to get him to use real serial killers as inspiration for the psychopaths such as the "Jack of Diamonds" killer (who is known for leaving the Jack of Diamonds with those he kills) and even "Quaker", who stalks his daughters killer for decades.  Billy goes as far as to place an advertisement in a newspaper inviting psychopaths to share their stories with Marty.

Marty also hangs out with a religious man named Hans Kieslowski (portrayed by Christopher Walken) who is trying to take care of his wife Myra (portrayed by Linda Bright), who is hospitalized for cancer.

One day, Billy and Hans steal a Shih Tzu named Bonny, unaware that it belongs to Charlie Costello (portrayed by Woody Harrelson), a violent gangster.  When one of Charlie's men named Paulo (portrayed by Zelijko Ivanek) finds out that Hans is connected to the kidnapping, they go to Billy's home where they threaten to kill Marty and Hans unless they reveal Bonny's location.  But the Jack of Diamonds killer arrives and kills Charlie's thugs.

Meanwhile, a murderer named Zachariah Rigby (portrayed by Tom Waits), responds to the ad in the newspaper.  And he tells Marty a story about how he rescued a girl named Maggie from a killer's basement long ago.  And the two became a couple and would become serial killers of actual killers.  Traveling around America and murdering killers.  But when he found Maggie to be to cruel in her methods of killing, the two split.  And Zachariah wants Marty to leave a message for Maggie at the end of the film if he plans to use his story in his screenplay.  And Marty swears on his life that he will.

As Hans is planning to visit his wife in the hospital, Charlie gets there before he does.  Very emotional about his dog being stolen and worried that his Bonny will be killed, he sends a message to Hans and his friends by killing Myra.

These events then lead to Billy killing Charlie's ex-girlfriend Angela (portrayed by Olga Kurylenko) and leading Marty, Billy and Hans to go on the run with Bonny.  And as Marty spends time with Billy and Hans in the middle of nowhere, he quickly learns that his two friends have a secret they have been hiding.  And as for Billy, he has invited Charlie and his men to come get his dog at their location, in hopes for a major shootout.

VIDEO, AUDIO & SUBTITLES:

"Seven Psychopaths" is presented in 2:40:1 anamorphic widescreen and English 5.1 Dolby Digital.  It's important to note that if you want the best picture quality possible for "Seven Psychopaths", you will want to purchase a Blu-ray review copy of the film.

As for the DVD, picture quality is as good as it gets on DVD.  Picture quality features very good detail and warm colors.  Closeups are very good and considering the film is shot outdoors, the DVD looks very good but obviously, I'm quite sure the Blu-ray version looks magnificent.

As for audio, the film is pretty much a dialogue driven film, so mostly the audio is center and front-channel driven.  There are some action scenes involving gunfire towards the end but for the most part, dialogue and music are clear.

Subtitles are in English SDH and Spanish.

SPECIAL FEATURES:

"Seven Psychopaths" comes with the following special features:

  Martin McDonagh's Seven Psychopaths - (2:31) Director Martin McDonagh talks about the film and its cast.
  Colin Farrell is Marty - (1:25) A short featurette about Colin Farell as Marty.
  Woody Harrelson is Charlie - (1:24) A short featurette about Woody Harrelson playing Charlie.
  Crazy Locations  - (2:09) A short featurette about where the film was shot.
  Layers - (1:05) A short featurette with video clips going along with Billy's beat boxing.

EXTRAS:

"Seven Psychopaths" comes with an Ultraviolet code which allows one to download the film to their computer and select Apple and Android devices and the ability to stream to computers, tablets or smartphones.

JUDGMENT CALL:

So far, leave it to Martin McDonagh to create unique films that are nothing like typical, banal Hollywood films.

The director who wowed audiences and film critics with "In Bruges" is back with a film that is a black comedy featuring amoral characters that literally builds into this standoff of who can be the better psychopath.

With two storylines within the film, one that involves a screenplay about "Seven Psycopaths" and the lead character trying to find inspiration for his film by talking to actual serial killers, the violent storylines that he tries to think up for his screenplay is quite fascinating, very violent but also humorous.

But it's the battle between Marty's friends vs. Charlie and his thugs that make the film worth watching.  While Marty is the most reserved, Hans is quiet, it's Billy that is the mysterious unknown character because at first, you think he's just a con-man, but the more the film continues, you realize that he is quite a psychopath.  And the fact that he has found his matchup, another psychopath, the notorious gangster known as Charlie is quite interesting.

Woody Harrelson plays a sensitive and crazy gangster who cares about his dog but will not hesitate to kill innocent people.  You need someone crazy to go against crazy and on Marty's side, you have the actor Sam Rockwell, always known for playing versatile roles, who matches up with Woody Harrelson's craziness with efficacy.  Especially as these two, will primarily the character of Billy, who seems he must outdo the craziness of Charlie.

As for Hans, his character is rather complex.  A quiet religious man, his nature tends to change after the murder of his wife Myra.  And you eventually learn more about him and also Billy, as the film continues.

As for the DVD release, first, I must say that this is a beautiful film and if you have a Blu-ray player, it's definitely worth checking out on Blu-ray.  But on DVD, the film does look and sound good, while I felt the special features was quite short at around under three minutes each.  So, I wish there were lengthier special features, maybe even an audio commentary.

Overall, "Seven Psychopaths" is unlike any film I have ever seen.  A dark comedy which the character Hans would even say "has many layers", but its the way the film was written and how the characters are presented, it definitely made this film much more satisfying.  An original and unique film with a lot of twists along the way, Martin McDonagh's "Seven Psychopaths" is recommended!

I watched this movie on the basis of the Rotten Tomatoes and Amazon reviews, which are largely positive. However, these reviews are probably from people who liked In Bruges, which I hated. I didn't realize until after I saw the movie that this is virtually the same cast and director as In Bruges

I thought that this was a pretty horrible movie. I suppose that movies like this are the American answer to the surreal French films. Which I don't like either.

So if you're not a fan of surreal movies and you didn't like In Bruges, then you're not going to like this movie either.

As far as I'm concerned this movie doesn't pass for entertainment. Nor does the twisted plot count for what I consider intellectual stimulation. There's a lot of movie blood (lots of people get either shot in the head or have their heads completely blown off). The plot meanders around. At the end its not clear whether the movie actually happened or whether it was just a screen play that the author was writing. Or what. But who cares.

I loved the actors and their performances were fine, but the script had too many misfires. We watched it all the way through because we always enjoy good actors chewing up the scenery, but in the end, they barely saved the movie.
its got some good parts in it  kind of odd i think it could have been a  lot better though

The Walkenisms abound. Great cars, great writing.
Woody and Farrell could not be better.
See this movie many times, too bad Deniro isn't one of the psychos.

This movie was terrible. I couldn't figure out if it was a comedy, action movie or both at the same time. That means it was neither. The only reason I watched it more than 20 minutes was I thought something entertaining would happen. It never did.
Was entertaining, but with a cast like that I had higher hopes for it. It was decent but I would have like a bit more in it.

I was pleasantly surprised with this movie. All the characters are great. I came for the Tom Waits, and left with the Sam Rockwell. Rockwell's character is definitely the standout, even though all the major actors in the movie excel. Walken's characters was unlike his other roles and very likable, and Colin Farrell was a great casting for the lead. Any movie with Waits in it, I'll watch, and this one definitely does not disappoint.
I love dark comedy, but this piece of garbage isn't funny in the least.  From a few moments of humor at the beginning it devolves into a stool of bloody fecal matter.
Smart humor and a clever plot, I haven't seen a movie like this in a while. Beware, its graphic but what do you expect? It's Seven Psychopaths!

I rated this 3 stars for one reason only, it doesn't deserve 4?

I ended that sentence with a question mark because I could almost give it a 4!

I ended the last sentence with an exclamation point for no real reason, the movie is worth a watch (but not a Rolex).
So it is worth watching, great actors in this movie and a decent plot...more of a reflection on bad ass movies than an actual bas ass movie...

The plot, after only one viewing seemed a little disjointed when paired with the variety of characters that are introduced. By the end however, the characters are engrossing enough to make you care about them by the end, which seems rarer and rarer these days. I also found myself laughing plenty throughout the film which is a huge plus.
Hilarious, but you must have a dark sense of humor. Love Christopher Walken in this movie. If you enjoyed In Bruges, this is a must see

I noticed that some of these reviewers state that if one loved "In Bruges" that one is sure to love this film by the same director.  With this in mind I rented it from Netflix.  It is humorless, trite, and filled with the type of overacting one associates with high school plays.  One can only wonder what advice the director gave Rockwell, who does everything but chew up the scenery.  His character is so obnoxious I was hoping he'd be killed off quickly.  No such luck.  Colin Farrell acts as though he doesn't want much to do with the entire enterprise - who can blame him?  If you enjoy watching films in which hardly anyone acts as a human being might act under similar circumstances then this film is for you.  Chris Walken's character's wife is killed and his reaction is to smile that Walken smile. He shows more emotion when he finds that his own life story has been pilfered by another character.  Really? For me, I wish they'd centered the film on Bonnie - the dog's a natural.  You've been warned.
Definitely NOT the movie I thought i was going to watch. If someone had said it was Tarrantino-esque I would have known better than to even try it. Wish I could get a refund.
Great cast, surprisingly slow and disappointing.  I really wanted it to be more and it just wasn't.  It tried too hard to be like Pulp Fiction.

I loved this movie! I love Sam Rockwell so that was enough to get me to want to see it. My mother watched it with me and unfortunately didn't really love it as much as I did. She prefers the traditional type movie. To me that means boring. I loved the humor, the actors, you just have to go with it and roll with it. It is a fun ride!

There is one scene in this movie that is worth it all between Christopher Walken and Woody Harrelson. That shows CW after his wife was murdered and him knowing  that Woody did it unexpected but beautifully done

How do you get to the point of being able to parody pop entertainment while creating outstanding, frontier-pushing examples of it? V-e-r-y carefully and likewise craftfully, would be my guess. Or maybe by just being who you are. Or maybe both?

Well, figure it out if you can, or care, and please let me know if you do.  But definitely add  this one  to your must-see list.

This is a little complex to watch at first but it evens out as you get into it and start to understand a little of what the relationships are.  This is a great film for anyone that is a fan of Quentin Tarentino.  It is very much in his style and holds back a lot of information as the plot unwinds.  Great movie for a snowy afternoon...

I had all but given up on Colin Farrell, but after this and "Horrible Bosses" I think he's found his niche.  The rest of the cast is outstanding.  Sam Rockwell Christopher Walken and Woody Harrelson carry off their roles in top-notch fashion. This is one funny movie.

This movie has a great cast and an interesting plot.  The characters are charming, funny, and bat crap crazy!  Very adult subject matter, language and graphic violence.  Not the words you would associate with funny, and yet it had me laughing to tears!
This movie was funny and very exciting with lots of crazy turns I did not expect Christopher Walken was great and makes every line exciting and his own.. Good movie
I wish I could have my 2 hours back!  Terrible attempt at a Quentin T. movie!  Great cast but just a terrible plot.

Christopher Walken, Tom Waits Work their quirkiness and - for the first time - I liked Colin Farrell's acting.
Threw in serial killers, a dog and some rabbits into the mix & a winner was produced.

2 psychopaths turn out to be 1 psychopath. Another psychopath is completely made up for script in this film. Even overlooking what the title clearly advertises to the viewer, this movie is just plain boring, unrealistic and feels like a amateurish beginner's attempt at script writing at a film school which is understandable for students, but not for directors. By the way, the trailer for Martin McDonagh's Seven Psychopaths lists off several characters that were not actually psychopaths in the Seven Psychopaths (both girls and the, "Seemingly normal," guy who is just a dorky writer caught in the middle of the plot).

Before I continue, note that I will count what the movie counted as psychopaths as I describe the plot to you. The plot starts with these 2 guys trying to write script for a film that they only have the title for (Seven Psychopaths), but one writer is secretly a serial killer and psychopath (1) who has knowingly stolen a dog and girlfriend from a gangster boss (2) while disguised as another mysterious psychopathic serial killer dressed in all black with a red scarf (3). Along the way, the writer and his friend (supposedly the writer's co-writer) write about a fictional psychopath who was formally a Vietcong soldier in the Vietnam War (4), interview an old serial killer (5) who once had a girlfriend (6) whom he traveled around with to kill famous serial killers and another self-mutilating psychopath (7) who tags along with the writer and his crazy friend throughout the story for the sake of having Christopher Walken in the movie and nothing more. The 2 friends and Christopher Walken are basically trying to outrun the gangster boss psychopath who wants his beloved dog back that the writer's friend stole. Contrary to the film's advertisement, the gangster boss' girlfriend and the writer's girlfriend are small side characters at best. However, the writer's crazy friend, supposed fellow writer and secret serial killer who dresses up in an all-black disguise is counted as 2 psychopaths, but I do not count this 1 psychopath as 2. The Vietcong psychopath is a fictional character made up for a writer's movie script in Seven Psychopaths. Even if it turned out that the Vietcong psychopath was based on a real person, it's hearsay at best in the film and, other than being mentioned occasionally, the Vietcong psychopath is pointless and not very entertaining overall.

There isn't much chaos or mayhem, it's not really that funny, most of the characters aren't really that psychotic and the ending is stupid and doesn't make much sense in director Martin McDonagh's dull and lacking Seven Psychopaths film. As dishonest as the advertisement is, the advertisement was way more entertaining than the actual movie itself.
Silly movie. I see why it didn't make it in the movies.  It is a rental worth watching because of the actors alone.
Movie was good overall, had some unexpected twists, and some dark humor. Liked the originality.  At times it seemed to dragged.
Who doesn't love Christopher Walken.  Loved the whole cast, the plot was cheeky.  Had a good ending.  I will definitely watch this again.
I really enjoyed the characters in this film. I liked the plot, too. My favorite (aside from Christopher) was Rockwell. His character is perfect!
This movie was pretty good, not great, but good.  Parts of it were funny, but I feel like I saw a lot of those in the previews...

Much to my surprise, Seven Psychopaths blew me away with it's originality and dark humor. Excellently written script with a strong cast. I love movies that are kind of rugged and weird...this film hits that head on.
I was disappointed by Ferrel's performance as he was the lead, but his supporting cast mates (Christopher, Woody, and Sam) steal the show enough to put this on top. Worth every penny, do not overlook Seven Psychopaths.
I applaud their meta story and taking chances on a novel narrative structure but the characters don't seem motivated by anything compelling. An interesting movie but not one I'd strongly recommend.
I kept waiting for something interesting to happen but was disappointed. So many good actors and nobody stepped up. Boring!!!!!
I like stars in the video/movie.  A hodgepodge script but entertaining enough.  I wouldn't watch it twice, blah, blah, blah (I needed three more words).
thought i knew what the movie was about.  was surprised on the way they went with it. i will have to buy this movie
I love the role of Billy Bickle played by Sam Rockwell. Woody Harleson is pretty good too. Three more words required.
Enjoyable, madcap, great cast except for Colin Farrell.  Walken is the catalyst that makes it all work and saves the film from itself.  Insufficient nudity.

The cast is great but the plot gets lost somewhere.  I really didn't mind as
  I expected to have fun and I did.

It was a so-so movie with a great cast. If you are a fan of Colin Farrell and Christopher Walken, then it is worth seeing. Otherwise, forget it. From the trailer, I was expecting a lot of laughs that it did not deliver.
Amazing to see these acters all together in the same movie. Wonderful story and a little understanding on how a Psychopaths brain works.
great bang bang shootemup movie.  Walken is, as usual, wildly entertaining.  Farrell does a great job being a wanker (not sure if acting...).  Woody is also great in this movie.

watched this movie on a rainy afternoon with my brother.  it was my choice so he went along hesitantly.  we laughed, punched each other in the arm and did a lot of rewinding to see if what we heard was what we thought we heard.  all in all a great movie, the idea of it is hard at times to wrap your arms around but very entertaining.  chris walken is amazing!  great movie to watch on a rainy afternoon!

My husband liked it more than me but I still thought it was interesting. May need to watch it twice to underhand it.
Update: watched it again and loved it. Maybe I wasn't paying attention the first time. Lots of twists and turns. Very good.
I thought it was funny.  Quirky funny, but funny.  Of course, Christopher Walker is always funny.  I would definitely recommend.
We loved this dark humorous movie. Classic Christopher Walken and the rest if the cast holds their own. Must see
This movie was insanely funny, great characters and plot. Walken makes this a fantastic movie a must watch Highly recommended!
Complete waste of time; poorly conceived, poorly acted. Whoever "green-lit" this project was and soon be again waiting tables. Rent End of Watch and watch it twice in place of this mistake.

I was really looking forward to seeing this movie. I couldn't understand why it was so advertised in movie trailers but didn't appear at any theaters. I found out why only after spending about $20 for the DVD. It was horrible. The cast was interesting but the premise was very strange. In the trailers it appeared to be funny. NOT! Very violent and bloody. Made absolutely no sense. One of the worst movies I've ever seen. Wish I could get my money back.
This movie was eh. The cast had potential, but as usual movies do not deliver. With the exception of Walken, there wasn't a character with any likability.
This is the kind of movie Quentin Tarantino would make if he weren't really good at making these kinds of movies.
Seven Psychopaths is trite playing to sterotypes, stupid at time but shows some silly sweetness/ heart & is violent/brutal --- tarantinoish.
Movie made no sense to me.  Great cast, but bad movie.  Had a hard time staying awake. Don't bother renting.

Quirky, twisty fun. An adult movie that doesn't dummy down and stop to explain everything.
It was a fun ride to the end. There are not many violent movies, that are deliberatly funny, and compelling,
make a movie night with your better half and enjoy.
This very random cast really does a bang up job. A great comedy / action flick. I was laughing the whole time!

I will start off by stating that this movie isn't for everyone. I hadn't heard of the movie, didn't see any trailers for it, so I went into it without any expectations. I chose to see it basically because the cast, and the title interested me.  I am so glad I chose to see it. I found this movie to just be plain out quirky fun. Thoroughly enjoyable. The humor is subtle and a bit dry. The script appears to be seemingly all over the place with a total lack of cohesion; I think that the writer wrapped it up together nicely in the end. There will be people who will say what did this have to do with that and so forth. In truth life is all over the place and lacks cohesion. The main focus is on one character and how random events in his life play out. We never know how people or events that occur will affect our lives. I find the story-line to be similar, except that this character finds inspiration in the strange happenings that is his life.

I recall people telling me they loved Seinfeld because it was a show about nothing, just nonsense. I'd imagine that people who enjoyed the quirkiness of that show would enjoy this film. It's sort of a fun nonsense.
Honestly, this show was so empty that I fell asleep during most of it.  Very disappointing considering the wonderful cast.

One of the worst movies I have seen in a long time -- was expecting much better given the cast. The humor and the plot runs out after 15 minutes, it's all awkward, stupid, rambling, random after that. A waste of time and money.
Whodathunkit? A witty, well acted film. In fact, if this were cast any other way, it wouldn't work. But the actors here make it.

A quirky dark comedy thriller making fun of Hollywood cliches and other movies of the genre. Great people - fun movie.
If you like this kind of thing, which I do

I was looking forward to seeing this move, after I saw the previews for it...I was disappointed.
The cast is perfect, in my opinion.  Each personality is great for the role he plays.  There were a few instances when I laughed out loud, but I felt most of it was "lacking."  Language...why do writers feel that bad language makes a movie better??  A word here and there, when it makes sense...okay, but, in my opinion; way too much in this movie.  Not the worst I have seen, but bad enough to make me sorry I rented it.  In my opinion, it doesn't enhance the movie, it lowers the movie down to a more ignorant level.
I gave Seven "Psychopaths" 3 stars for the cast and for the few clever and funny instances in it.  If not for that, it would have gotten 1 star from me.

As a huge Christopher Walker fan, I rented this with no hesitation.. If you're looking for that funny action movie that the trailer said you will get, you will be disappointed.. A serviceable movie.. But fell short of the trailer
Not my favorite, but well crafted n the very black humor department.  Lots of murder aqnd physcopaths as indicated.  The plot is surprisingly good!
Movies are specific to the person, so while I may not have loved this movie, it doesn't mean you won't love it.  It was nice to be able to see it on the computer while I was traveling.
this movie is funny and has some graphic scenes, overral a good movie. You won't be disappointed if you rent this movie or even buy it. Well worth it.

My boyfriend and I rarely watch movies, but we heard great things about this one so we rented it from amazon. It was a very well-written story with 'lots of layers' as Christoper Walken says. I'm not a big fan of violence, and this had plenty, but the story line was so good I still enjoyed the movie.
Pretty funny, different kind of story. I like most of the actors in it so I was pretty sure I would like the movie

Ok.  Good actors, supposedly.  Good writers, supposedly.  Christopher Walken.  Should be a balls out 4 at least right?  The narrative is slow.  The action is inthe trailer for the film.  I admit it had some good humor and some characters were decently crafted.  But that's why it gets 2.5.  The actors did a good job with what they had to work with, and oddly enough walken was not the most memorable one, still he added a good deal, but the plot after 45 minutes gets boring and the film drags on and on and on.  Much like this review would if I didn't say this: 2.5 stars at best, good acting, WALKEN!, humor... Everything else was boring.  And hats coming from some one that thought The Salton Sea was a great drama and also a fantastic comedy movie.

This movie felt like a combination of the movies "Be cool" and "Get Shorty" only more violent. I regret not seeing this on the big screen. Very well written and funny as hell, although you may need to have a dark sense of humor. It's definately a movie worth checking out.
Total waste of my time and money! Awful plot. Really expected more from this group of actors. Did not enjoy this at all
Christopher Walken always has a great screen presence.  I thought this was going to be a tragically hip movie, but it turned out to be very good with believable charcters
The movie wasn't what I expected, but was good. Not sure about whether I'd re-watch it again--probably after some time. I liked it for what it was.

The movie has a tedious and slow start.  But if you hang with it and enjoy watching a whole new genre of crime scenes you just might enjoy this movie.  Christopher Walken steals the show with his deadpan lines.  My favorite is when he delivers this line to Marty who is studying psychopaths for his movie script, "You're the one that thought psychopaths were so interesting. They get tiresome after a while, don't you think?" In this movie, McDonagh shows you another side of psychopaths, for example, killers who target serial killers.  Psychopaths that take out the bad guys.  If nothing else it gets you do think about personality disorders in a different way. After all, doesn't it feel like we are surrounded by personality disorders?
It had a very good cast, a creative script and was well directed. It's worth a few hours and a few dollars.

The story line is more in depth than just a typical shoot em up flick . The cast in this movie is fantastic, they each bring their skill set and unique charisma together in such a way that the film flows well. If you are a fan of sarcasm , than this movie will be up your alley , for they lather it on  like peanut butter.

I'm sure watching this movie was like staring at a solid black canvas and hearing the person next to you mumble "Isn't it awesome?" Someone, somewhere, understood this movie and enjoyed it. That would not be me. Slow, stupid and the worst part is I forced myself to watch it hoping I'd understand it later and enjoy it. I didn't.
This movie is a breath of fresh air, interesting, funny, and unique. It features a wonderful cast and an original screenplay; a definite must-see.
Only these actors could pull off the characters of this movie as well as they did. A funny movie with some touching parts without a doubt.
Very likeable and crazy ( in a good way).  Keeps you in suspense.  I throughly enjoyed it.  Colin Farrell was excellent.

Better than tarantino, sarcasm at its best.
Surprising, funny, not too gore.
A recipe for a perfect evening, or a date?

Definitely not understanding all of these 1 star reviews.  I don't think it's necessarily full 5 star material, but I wanted to balance some of the bad reviews out.  It's a fun movie that is original, not something you see every day which is hard to find in a film these days.
Not only is this forgettable, but a poorly written script. Seven good actors, or 1 all-star cast, does not make for a decent movie.
It's not the greatest thing ever produced... but it was entertaining enough to watch.  It would be even better at under $2 from Red Box!

Whoever wrote this movie needs to be tar feathered. And the director needs to be raaped
This movie was so bad o would give it negative stars.
Script is all over the place.  Movie was surprisingly disappointing.  Terrible movie for such a good cast.  Not even sure why the actors liked the script.
Can I get my money back? please.  Really can I get my money back?  NO, NO, really can I get my money back?
One of the funniest movies i've seen in a long time. I don't get excited about movies very often, but i loved this one.

We were excited to see this. We wanted to see it at the Movies, but didn't have time so we waited and rented it. It was just ok, it was a pretty odd movie actually. It was fun to watch, but as I said it was odd. I would say watch it when you have time but just know that if you wait until next weekend to watch it that the world is not over, it will hold until next weekend.

Loved it - really did.  Great acting, great characters and great dark humor.  Worth checking out this whacky dark comedy.  I mean, Christopher Walken being, well, Christopher Walken - do I need to say more!?!
This movie was really bad. Would not reccomend to anyone. I was really surprised with the actors in it and how bad this movie was.
Too bloody, not for me. Did not even come close to watching even half of it. Too violent and off the wall for me

It's okay. Not great, not even good. Just okay, the sort of movie that leaves little trace much alone thought in your mind. Woody Harrelson does perhaps the best job of all portraying a bad ass gangster with a soft spot for his dog. The other actors are practically sleepwalking through their lines with the exception of Collin Farrell. Olga Kurilenko makes a far too short appearance. Again, it's okay if you're not too demanding and like to unwind in front of insipid, and unstimulating visuals. If that's not you, then you should pass.

It seemed a little derivative in some ways, but unique in others. The action movie genre is so stale - I think they did a good job of incorporating good actors and memorable writing to keep it interesting for the non-target audience. I'd like to see more of these movies than the typical shoot-em-ups.
Great plot, love a movie within a movie when it's done right.  The actors are matched really well with their characters.  Two really big thumbs up!

I love the actors in this movie, it's a bit strange, but what would you expect when the title is Seven Psychopaths?  I love anything with Christopher Walken, so if you a fan of CW, then you must see this movie.
I really liked this film, once again Christopher Walken does a spectacular job as always and the others were right along with him!

This movie tries a stab at dark humor in the vein of Pulp Fiction. Boozy writer Marty (Colin Farrell) is a man in search of a screenplay. He has a catchy title but no story to go along with it. Marty has a couple of oddball buddies, Hans (Christopher Walken) and Billy (Sam Rockwell), who make a living by kidnapping rich people's dogs, then returning them and collecting the reward. However this time, the fur flies when Hans and Billy kidnap the beloved pooch of a gangster (Woody Harrelson), and Marty uses the ensuing events as fodder for his screenplay.

Although there are some moments where it appears that it will succeed it untimately fails to find any humor dark or otherwise or any sensible storyline. If you like Pulp Fiction, you will be disappointed in this one because this movie tries hard but fails miserably to be a Pulp Fiction.

I'm a little bias, I'm a big walken fan. Funny and entertaining.
I Needed 8 more words to post this.
Very unusual and funny movie. Christopher Walken and the others are great! Some bloody parts, but hey, it is about psychpaths.

This is a brilliantly written dark comedy that takes you on a roller coaster of emotions without losing its comedic essence. However, the movie's true beauty is in the narrative of social and human issues through the lives and experiences of these insanely humane psychopaths.

Colin Farrell, Christopher Walken, Sam Rockwell, Woody Harrelson, Tom Waits, Harry Dean Stanton, usually these actors are the most interesting performer on-screen at any given time. The fact that they the fact that they are all on hand in Seven Psychopaths, let's you know that straight away you are in for a treat

Coming from writer-director Martin McDonagh, whose great In Bruges was released a little over four years ago to great acclaim and a Golden Globe win for it's star, Colin Farrell, the star here. Seven Psychopaths has many of the same qualities as In Bruges, it is a clever and well written cross pollinated comedy and crime drama.

Taking a self aware approach to the art of moviemaking, it is set in the outskirts of the movie industry and it's lead characters are an actor (Rockwell) and a screenwriter (Farrell). The writer is working on a script cheekily titled "Seven Psychopaths", he needs to find said psychopaths so his friend places a personal ad that attracts at least one crazy (Waits) to him.

But he doesn't have to look far as psychopaths are all around him. First his buddy is running a dog kidnapping for profit scheme with an older man (Walken), who comes with a series of surprises. They unknowingly abduct the dog of a mobster (Harrelson) who will stop at nothing to get his four legged friend back.

Full of quirky and very funny situations that don't seem as if they will add up in the end, but they surely do. Where this picture is going is never clear, but it is a lot of fun getting there. It doesn't lead itself to the heights of In Bruges, but it comes mighty close. Using the same kind of violence and compassion laced with loads of humor, it is all played as a joke this time around, but still one with a lot ofv bloodshed.

Like Quentin Tarantino, McDonagh has an ear for clever witty dialogue. Also like Tarantino he takes a rather mundane, perhaps worn out premise and turns it inside out, finding knowledgeable new ways to tell an old story.

As a send of the movie industry, Seven Psychopaths has a  lot of fun attacking conventions and clichés. It feels often like it is bound to loose it's self, but McDonagh has a good knowing directing style that helps keep everything in check.

And that cast, I don't know what more can be said for it except it is spot on for this sort of absurdist satirical movie. Not the funniest movie of the year, I still think Killer Joe was, still there are a lot of good laughs that come from the sharp words spoken by a quirky bunch you will not see this season. The whole cast is at the top of their collective game and Farrell has found a collaborator in McDonagh who works towards his strengths, something the big Hollywood productions like the Total Recall and Fright Night reduxes have not done.

An intense and refreshing movie, and there are so few of them released any more. Seven Psychopaths is a little gem that was sort of lost amongst the bigger more high profile movies of the fall. Now on blu-ray and DVD, hopefully this minor masterpiece will find the adoring audience that it most deserves.

Martin McDonagh made his feature film debut when he wrote and directed the improbable hit man black comedy "In Bruges" in 2008. "Seven Psychopaths" bears his signature violence, political incorrectness, and dark humor. A mystery assassin known as the "Jack of Diamonds Killer" is running around Los Angeles killing criminally violent people. Meanwhile Marty (Colin Farrell), a frustrated screenwriter, is stuck partway through a storyline that was given to him by his friend Billy (Sam Rockwell), partner of Hans (Christopher Walken) in a dog-kidnapping racket. Billy and Hans steal dogs from rich people and return them for a reward. But this time Billy has kidnapped Bonny, a Shih Tzu belonging to Charlie Costello (Woody Harrelson), a violent single-minded gangster who really wants his dog back...and who may have met his match in Billy.

McDonagh's films can never be accused of being hackneyed. This is a fresh, thoughtful, multi-layered satire. It's violent. It's very funny at times. But "Seven Psychopaths" is so thematically complex and reflexive that I often felt that McDonagh was overthinking the whole thing. Reflexive to the point of self-mockery, placing revenge narratives within revenge narratives, satirizing violent movies and their audience while exploiting them to make a point, the film is certainly clever. But perhaps it is more clever than good. Its comment on revenge is strange and a little inscrutable. Sam Rockwell plays Billy's crazy character to great effect. But the racial component is also strange, and the whole exercise is so crowded with ideas that it loses coherence. Sometimes McDonagh hits the mark with his brash dialogue. Other times, he falls flat.

"You're the one who thought psychopaths were so interesting. They're kind of tiresome after a while, don't you think?" says Hans to Marty. And that is, ironically, the idea behind a film about seven psychopaths. Original and occasionally shocking, "Seven Psychopaths" is not for the easily offended. Unfortunately, it suffers from too much of a good thing, and a lot of redundancy, packed into a super-violent dark satire that gets unbearably serious at times. I love the cast, and they give some gutsy performances. Making movies about movies is always tricky, but stripping half the material out might have made a better film. There are no bonus features on the regular DVD (Sony 2013). Subtitles are available in English, English SDH, and Spanish.

Two of my favorite actors Christopher Walken and Colin Ferrell but was disappointed in this movie. Saw a couple of clips before I purchased the movie and was expecting something totally different. I thought it was a comedy and although it had some humor in it,I didn't care for it.

Due in great part to the commercial adverts, I went into this thinking there would be a literal seven nutters carrying a multitude of high powered and/or bladed weapons in the mold of a Guy Ritchie-esque hardcore twisted comedy. Discovering that the plot revolved around three guys and a dog... well, it certainly wasn't what was being sold in the promotionals.

However, that said, once past fallen expectations I found myself slowly enjoying this quirky flick. The further along into the film, the better it got. Very much like my experience with 'Cloud Atlas'.

The Seven Psychopaths is the title of a proposed movie that a part-time screenwriter and full-time alcoholic is creating. Tired of the same ol' same ol', Colin Farrell's character, Martin, has a vision to do something completely fresh and original. Seven vignettes of various psychopaths, their lives and their deeds or misdeeds expressed on film.

Not a particularly original or novel concept; which was, apparently, the point.*

Marty's two best friends and would-be muses are Bill, a brash loudmouth wannabe actor who seemingly has no clue that he's an obnoxious windbag with serious anger issues. And Hans, the sweet old veteran of the team whose life revolves around caring for his cancer ridden wife. The two work as small time schlubs whose criminal endeavors are infinitely less impressive or fantastical - and unsuitable to be Marty's inspiration - pathetically going about stealing pet dogs and holding onto them for the reward money.

And as the screenplay moves along, Bill desperately attempts to interject himself into the creative process. The intimation being that he's an ego whore in constant need of reflective fame. But is that really what drives his insistent attempts to contribute to the script? Still, after sharing a particularly bizarre tale about a father and his murdered daughter, Marty decides that maybe he has something to offer after all and invites him to be a co-writer, much to Bill's everlasting joy and boundless enthusiasm.

An enthusiasm that will bring Marty closer than he ever wanted to his imagined seven psychopaths.

Like a pungent antisocial onion, each revelation exposes the increasingly freakish connections between the outrageous fiction of the screenplay and the real-life experiences of the characters we meet throughout the film. Culminating in a hilarious, if predictable finish, as the three friends stumble into their respective destinies.

If what I've read is true, then success of the film is found in spite of itself; less an accomplishment and more a pleasant surprise - likely to the filmmakers themselves.

*Apparently, this was Director Martin McDonagh's attempt at satirizing the American movie mythology; a deconstruction of our "ideal" film and its archetypes. If that's accurate, then he failed. 'Psychopaths' doesn't properly draw out the comical to an absurd effect. Instead, while exploiting the same content, the film doesn't extract itself from the repetitive retread themes and stock characters he's attempting to skewer. His movie fell into the same trap.

That being said, Walken and Rockwell are fabulous, always the highlight of any movie for me. This was semi predictable, but I enjoyed it to the end. I LOVED this movie! This was the most hilarious movie I have seen in a VERY long time! I love Christopher Walken when he plays "Quirky, Funny" Characters, and that is the reason I decided to watch this movie.  As I suspected, Walken was Amazing as a 60 something "Dog Kidnapper" named "Hans" with a sad past and a challenging present. Hans was quirky, compassionate and a great friend to Sam Rockwell's Character, Billy.

Billy was an Actor who was having a tough time getting parts because of his temper. He was a longtime friend of Marty's, Colin Ferrel.  Marty was writing his new screenplay called "Seven Psychopaths" and was having a terrible time choosing the Psychopaths, and grappling with what kind of a message he wanted his movie to portray. Billy took it upon himself to "Help" Marty find the Seven Psychopath Characters and help write the plot of the movie, only after much discussion and arguing whether Marty wanted his help or not. Billy comes up with finding characters in some unconventional ways and hilarity ensues.

In the meantime Billy kidnaps his girlfriends,"Gangster" boyfriend, Charlie's, (Harrelson) beloved dog. Charlie is crazy in love with his little dog and cares more for the dog than the humans around him. Harrelson plays this role of the "Psychopath Gangster" perfectly!  Charlie tells his goons to find the kidnapper and get his dog back, one thing leads to another and Charlie finds out Billy has his dog.

Billy, Marty and Hans go into the dessert to work on the "Script" and Billy tries to make Marty write the movie the way he wants it to be. There are arguments, alcohol, and peyote consumed, and things are revealed that Marty can't deal with. Billy doesn't want Marty to leave, so he makes them stranded out in the desert and he calls Charlie to tell him to come and get his dog. Billy leaves them with only one choice and that is to end Marty's movie his way.

Sam Rockwell stole the show with his hilarious portrayal of Billy! Colin Ferrel was a great "Martin," as Hans would call him. Martin had his hands full with his friend Billy, and Ferrel did a great job of mixing comedy with humility throughout the movie. The three characters couldn't have been played by anyone else in my opinion!

The acting was SUPERB! This is a "must see" if you like to be thoroughly entertained and laugh out loud through a whole movie!

Another winner from Martin McDonagh. In Bruges is in my top ten favorite movies list and Seven Psychopaths is inching its way onto that list as well. Clever dialogue and equally amazing actors. This movie is quick paced and witty. I can't wait for McDonagh's next film.

This was a BRILLIANT movie. It was funny, thrilling, suspenseful, and dramatic. To be frank this isn't your typical run of the mill gangster/revenge/action flick. If you were expecting this movie to be solely about violence / vengence like "Godfather" / "Scarface"/"Goodfella's" and follow the formula of classic gangster films then you will definitely NOT like this movie. This is one of the movies that you will either love or hate. Despite what people may think, this movie isn't about vengence. It attempts to showcase the ludicrousness of violence, and the impact it has on everything (people, places, lives, etc.). Another thing that made this movie different was that it attempted to mock various genre's and break apart stereotypes. Some may not get the jokes, but others will. I for one, thought they were creative, witty, and clever. The characters were very interesting as well. They were decently developed and brought a great deal of intelligence, comic relief, and drama to the film. I was very pleased with the end result and would definitely include this in my Christmas gift list.

{3.5 stars} SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS is a cleverly plotted film where nobody is who they appear to be and nothing quite goes as planned. It's a "noir humor" film in the same tradition as Fargo,Natural Born Killers, and Meeting Evil, and takes the subgenre one step further by spoofing these other spoofs. Several interesting premise-characters here, including a psychopathic killer who only kills other psychopathic killers and a hack screenwriter (expertly played by Colin Farrell) whose constipated work-in-progress oddly coincides with his friends' and adversaries' own predicament. Oh, and let's not forget the ruthless cutthroat gangster whose beloved Shih Tzu's been kidnapped by the screenwriter's associates. Yep, many interesting characters and details of conflict: The deranged Vietnamese priest also deserves mention. The thematic dialogue carries a good bit of this film and, especially toward the end, is very original and quite amusing, though not in a truly "lol" sense of the word. Copious amounts of schlocky blood and gore throughout. Also, while there's nothing inherentirely misogynistic about the film itself, the harsh, constant "male-talk" about women-in-general is not likely to resonate with many female audiences. Yet, for all its colorful ideas and details, as well as some very effective satire of modern society, SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS does not quite have the creative punch of other films of its type, including any of the three excellent works mentioned. It's entertaining and not entirely predictable, but it gets tiresome in places and always seems on the verge of derailment.

This is a movie about a screenwriter and his dog snatching buddy that wants to be an actor, and also wants to be part of the writing team for his new screenplay called Seven Psychopaths.  Which is about seven psychopaths.  It gets interesting as fact and fiction get blurred is what your seeing real or is it part of the screenplay.
I was very mixed on my review of this film, sometimes the movie is really uneven, but when the movie is good it is really good. There are some great performances by Christopher Walken and Tom Waits.  Sam Rockwell is okay he just needed to get reigned in a bit his performance is kind of all over the place.  Colin Farell was the real let down, he's the lead, and I just didn't connect with him at all he wasn't really likable at all.

I will say this movie has one hell of an opening scene that really throws you into it, I only wish the movie could have kept up that pace and the dark comedy timing, but after that it kinda falls apart, it reminded me a lot of the movie Smokin' Aces, which I've grown to love over time, and this film could be the same but for now it's pretty good boarding on okay.

I laughed out loud three to four times, some of it's hard things to laugh about, the movie is basically about death and accepting it, not the funniest of subject matter and a hard sell for most people.

I'd recommend this movie to fans of Tarentino's work and fans of Smokin' Aces and Christopher Walken

Not sure how this stuff gets financial support, but not only was it an extremely dull movie, it made absolutely no sense at all. I didn't feel bad for anyone in the movie and just a plain waste of time and money.

I started watching this after watching the preview, which gave the impression that it was a comedy starring some wonderful actors. I stopped watching after about 40 minutes, after seeing horrible, extreme violence, over and over. I'm sorry, but watching people being shot through the eyes, having limbs hacked off and burned alive is not funny!
It's a movie that delivers more than you might expect from a film titled "Seven Psychopaths". It's got the gore and violence, but with surprisingly deeper themes and witty dialogue.
great plot i liked how it has several mind twisters in there. I don't want to spoil it. it worth a watch or two.
It's a good watch and has a great cast with very distinct personalities. Highly recommend if your sense of humor is a little off

THIS is one of the MOST refreshingly, entertaining films I have seen in a long time...but then, what else can we expect from the stellar casting and story. I make these comments with NO RESERVATIONS !

Loved it! Great acting and screenplay. There is some blood but it just makes it better. Feels like a Tarritino.

In the vein of Tarantino you find yourself pulling for some of these psychopaths to win out in the end, very entertaining but be warned it is violent and they're not shy about showing it on the screen.

We were very pleasantly surprised and even charmed in this intimate story, great characters, casting, and well directed.

Martin McDonagh's first film "In Bruges" about two inept hired killers went underground in Bruges, Belgian was brilliant, funny and violent with smart dialogue.
This time he rounded up a great cast again headed by Colin Farrell about a minor Hollywood screenwriter who got into a lot of trouble after unable to proceed
with writing a script, named:  Seven Psychopaths!
There were some stories within stories and some eye catching locations including, sunny Hollywood, Joshua Tree, etc. but with rampant killings.
Is it supposed to be a satire against Hollywood?  Are we really living in this crazy world with people killing each others like flipping a switch?
Where are the motives?  Where are the narratives that make any sense?  What is the point of this movie?
Once again, a great group of acting talent has been wasted by a poorly conceived and written script and an indulgent director.
From "In Bruges" to "Seven Psychopaths" is like going from top to bottom.
Even the great Christopher Walken couldn't save the day.
Go watch "In Bruges" instead.
With all these great actors ,thought it would have been pretty good , but the total opposite , possibly worst movie I ever saw

so this is a bunch of screen writers saying, let's just do our lives meets resevoir dogs... misses at showing me anything imaginative, Will never make a pimple on tghe butt of anything the Cohen Bro.s have ever done. Great acting, aside from a perpetually constpated looking Ferrill, but they had nowhere to go with it. Gay; not in a good way.

Excellent movie. The most difficult part of reviewing it is trying to determine what you like best. Martin Mcdonagh's clever cracking of the fourth wall is brilliant, but Christopher Walken is amazing. Mcdonaghs writing and directing are amplified that much more by the perfect casting of pretty much every character. the scoring and sound track are a fantastic companion to the hilarious zany depressing story developments. I've been ridiculously enamored with P.P. Arnold after hearing her version of "the first cut is the deepest". Proving himself once more to be the master of black comedy, Martin Mcdonagh strikes again.
Odd, quirky and very funny movie! Sam Rockwell and Christopher Walken are hilarious. Makes you want to write your own screenplay about psychopaths.

LOVE LOVE LOVE this movie! Have seen it three times already & still surprised to catch things I missed. Violent, dark-themed, and laugh-out-loud funny, Seven Psychopaths is a movie for those who love Pulp Fiction & others in the same vein. Teenagers approve, too, which is a plus, but of course, you have to know your kids.
Bottom line, hilarious.

Entertaining and sometimes that's all I need. These guys are usually fun to watch in anything they do. one more word
.
