Seven Psychopaths is a hard film to review. To describe the plot details would be to ruin the film, plus-it's not the easiest film to really write a synopsis for. I'll try to keep it simple: Screenplay writer struggling to come up with a story for his latest movie gets help with the plot from a good friend of his, who also happens to be a dog nabber. One day he nabs the wrong pooch-a little shih tzu named Bonnie who happens to belong to a really dangerous guy. Stuff happens, bad stuff ensues. The name of the film comes into play throughout, but again, I won't spoil what each psychopath stands for. This film clearly wants to be comedic in nature, but it has quite a few dramatic moments that don't really feel out of place. There is LOTS of blood, gore and violence. Some of it almost seems for violence sake, but you get a sense of what this film will be like from the very first moments. Someone reviewed and stated it was 'all nudity'. I think I can maybe think of one scene in the whole movie that had any nudity and it really wasn't all that lurid. I don't know what that person was watching, but it wasn't this.

The movie looks great in Blu-ray and sounds great too. It's filled to the brim with great actors and each one brings their own thing to the table. Yes, some of it is overacting but here it works quite well. There are some twists and surprises, some a tad predictable, but I thought it was an interesting film. Not to be taken seriously. People who enjoy dark comedies, and don't mind violence will get a kick out of this. Again, a few people are complaining about a lack of plot. Not every plot has to be linear and full of thousands of details. I am usually pretty picky with films but couldn't really find anything major to complain about. Just a bunch of cool actors clearly having a grand time on film. Give it a shot!
This was a waste of 2 hours and $5. Watched it to humor my husband, but he hated it too. Bottom-line: boring, no plot, bad acting.

This is the second movie from Martin McDonagh and I find it every bit as good as his first film (In Bruges). It is different from the first, so if that's what you're looking for, look elsewhere. The cast, writing and directing are great and I would recommend this film to anyone.
Not what you are expecting. a thoughtful drama about craziness and one writer's goal to write a script about a fascinating title. Oh, and the psycho is NUTS! Enjoyable and fun and a little sad.

I think it's supposed to be comedy, but it's such a thoroughly bizarre kind of humor that I only chuckled once or twice...

Acting was quite good and directing seemed fine too, but the story itself was just strange.  The movie had no theme.
How can a movie have this many stars and suck so bad? 7 Psychos pulls it off. Not worth a free rental at redbox.
This movie was terrible, hard to watch, slow moving, terrible acting, almost as if the actors were "on something" while filming this.

Any movie with Sam Rockwell as one of its main characters is bound to be quirky and entertaining. The entire cast is marvelous. It was interesting to see Colin F as a meek protagonist, the silent, creative type. I could go on about all the cast: Walken, Harrelson, and Waits add their own unique style as well. If you like movies such as Fargo, then don't miss out on The Seven Psychopaths. An ingenious screenplay.
barely a plot, all nudity and offensive language. i would definitely not recommend this to anyone. can't believe i spent money on it
Very funny story line, and a super cast. Just Awesome. it's just so funny. And what a cast, like I said, just Awesome

I read numerous positive reviews for Seven Psychopaths and decided to buy it based on the cast. I've enjoyed Woody Harrelson, Colin Farrell, Sam Rockwell and Christopher Walken in separate outings so this was a can't lose situation, I thought. I paid full price for this unfunny piece of crap and can't give it away to anyone I care anything about. It's a stupid waste of time and talent about a dognapping that leads to lots of senseless killings. I love action and good horror films but here, the kills are mostly played for laughs and it ain't funny. I also didn't get the out of place racial slurs which pretty much target everyone. Even sexual preferences are targeted on numerous occasions. Gabourey Sidibe is called fat at least 4 times during the 5 minutes or so she's on film and it's demeaning, not funny. Bottom line, Seven Psychopaths sucks and I'm not going near another Martin McDonagh film. He's trying to be Tarantino but needs to try something else. The only thing I enjoyed was the adorable Shih Tzu dog and centerpiece of this crapfest. If the dog was well rewarded, then this turd isn't a total abomination.
Excellent movie! Very well written, more than just a surface story and SUPERB acting. (I really need to work on my Christopher Walken impersonation.)

Rather then give this a 1,I give it a 5 because there is no option for " VIDEO DID NOT PLAY CORRECTLY,GOT HUNG UP LIKE THE OLD VCR TAPES WOULD GET STUCK IN THE PLAYER.I couldn't watch the movie past the 1st 6 minutes. I cancelled the rental because of this. I was looking forward to seeing it too. I like Christopher Walken.
All the gore of a zombie movie without all the trendy zombies,  quite funny to boot.  Who doesn't love them some Christopher Walker?!

PLease save your money and wait until it comes on tv before purchasing.  Btw, this is the very first time I have ever not recommended a movie!

Honestly I don't get it.  If it was made for laughs Id understand.  There were moments but the movie felt like a bunch of skits put together(i.e, saturday night live) badly.  Honestly think they should use the money creating this movie to add more affect in saturday night live lol.  2 stars ive seen worse.
This was an enjoyable dark comedy.  There were some twists and turns that I did not except, but it was fun to watch and I strongly recommend!!
If you like Christopher Walken's sense of humor, then this is the movie for you.  Very witty and worth the time.
You gotta love Christopher Walken. The entire cast was wonderful. Every psych better than the last. Like how all they all ride in together

This movie had a great cast. With Colin Farrell speaking his native brogue, It reminded so much of early Tarantino. Again, how many places can you shoot (pun intended) a movie in Ca? "The Salton Sea", Joshua Tree thing end of the world....end of life...."A good place to die"..........AWESOME

First I liked that the actors were not type cast. Farrell, non-violent and Walken a Quaker. Woody was an incredible bad guy. Action, laughs and a crazy plot. All in All, an enjoyable movie.
With this lineup, how could it fail?  Alas.  Maybe it was just me not paying the proper attention but it was kind of hard to keep my brain on the ball.  Maybe I shouldn't have had that third bourbon?

Sure it's a little shocking and has violent moments, but if you can get past this the movie has an interesting narrative and has some very funny moments too. I was surprised by the chemistry between the characters, it's excellent. I personally think this could become a classic. I'm not a big violence fan, and I found a few moments difficult to watch, but it was such an interesting movie it won me over.
But I may not be quite right in the head. Some parts were hard for me with the blood/gore but they weren't long or too frequent. I laughed quite a bit. Walken rocks!
I liked it. It was a little twisted, but it was cool for sure. Woody H. helped things out too.
classic Walken. my wife and i both enjoyed this movie...more than i thought i would. it is worth the rental.
Ichoose this rating becuase the movie was an outside the box production always keeping yopu on your feet and thinking,very entertaining and very well acted,the charchters worked well together
I really enjoyed this movie. It has a entertaining plot which keeps it interesting. And you have to love Christopher Walken right?

I watched this movie in the theater and couldn't wait for the blu ray to come out!  It's a great movie, not the "common" type of humor or regular Hollywood style movie but very creative and interesting.
For reference, I like different types of movies (Inglorious Bastards, Little Miss Sunshine, Volver, Matrix, Kill Bill, etc), movies with good stories and good acting rather than movies more focused on special effects and such (I like those too but still value the acting more than the special effects).
I like the way the story is told, the actors in the movie and the way they put it all together - and will definitely watch it again!
If you thought Bridesmaids was the funniest....move on!  If you liked "Heathers", you are home!  This is a DARK comedy.  I have not seen a movie where I was giggling through out in a long time!!!

I rate this a total iWup. (I watch if you pay) It wasn't the worse movie I ever watch. Had some good parts. I liked all the characters except Collin Farrell's. I think because of Collin's acting.  He is a total hunk but I could tell he was acting. THe story did hold my attention most of the movie however, the car and desert scene were a bit of a bore.  I do wish I hadn't paid to watch though.

For the first time in I can't remember when, I had to turn a movie off as it was just too bloody; therefore, I could not tell you how good or poor the acting was as there is only so much throat slitting I can take!

I didn't really know what to expect with this movie, but it was surprisingly good. It wasn't at all what I thought it was going to be like. The dog made the movie seem a little gimmicky from the trailers, but it turned out to be funny, entertaining, and interesting.

Great actors but the story line was OK. For having these actors it was  little non exciting.

Starts right off with a BANG ! Love the twists and turns ,good supply of actors all performed very well . Chris Walken still has my attention, don't get me wrong Woody and Colin are great as well , I just love Mr. Walken no matter what hes in...

The flick had good actors and acting as well as a  gore and comedy, classic style.
I'm recommending it to the less timid.
Very good cast and entertaining storyline throughout. Christopher Walken still has it and Sam Rockwell is zany as ever. Worth the money.

Best film of 2012.
Absolute must see. Very intelligent, great story, beautiful performances from the cast (especially Christopher Walken). A lot of unexpected bloody violence, so be prepared. Reminiscent of 2011 Drive with Ryan Gosling
From the moment the movie opens it is a non-stop, crazy, unpredictable thrill ride. Very Well Written, Amazing Cast, Creative, Funny and Unpredictable.

Disorganized story line with absolutely no follow thru. Don't waste your money even in a dvd rental.
I never stop watching a movie half way but this was so terrible even watching it seemed like a total waste of my time.
The story was a feeble attempt to create cohesion among the 7.  I'm getting sick of the violence for violence sake.  This will be the last of this kind of movie for me...

I thought this movie would be good because I really like Christopher Walken and Woody Harrelson, but I was disappointed.  Their acting was fine. i just couldn't get into this movie.  I could tell that the plot was meant to have some silliness and humor, but I didn't find it funny. I just kept waiting for the movie to get better, but it never did.

This was one of the worst movies.  I believe it tried to be Tarantino-like with multiple plots, however it was so slow.  We watched 15 minutes of the movie and honestly after 5 minutes, I knew this was a royal stinker of huge proportions.

Too many psychopaths so little time.  How can it get any better than an irish drunk author narating a screen play about psychopaths in which the willful psychopaths themselves are intent on creating the storyline?

When I decided to watch this, I was looking for something light.  A story about a guys that kidnaps dogs for the reward...  ok that could be funny.  He kidnaps a dog from the head of the local mafia and chaos ensues...  definately getting there.  Woody Harrelson, Christopher Walken, Sam Rockwell, and Colin Farrell... this is probably pretty good.  It was definately OK.  I laughed a little, but not as much as I thought I would.  I mostly laughed at what was in the trailer.  I wish I had waited for cable.

Watching the trailer, you would think this film is about Seven Psychopaths, seven people, right? Nope. It's basically a low-budget premise movie that really is a B-movie masquerading as a blockbuster. Seriously. This is the sort of caliber of movie that would have been a bad B-movie in the 90's. Some guy got lucky with this script, I'll tell you that. I would advise skipping this movie, because it really stinks.
Love the actors. I cannot believe that actors of their caliber would choose to act in such a poorly written show.
It was funny to me and my husband, but we have a very dry sense of humor. But kind of slow at times. It was just OK though.

I wanted to see this movie as soon as it came out in the theater, I missed it so was happy to see it on Amazon for rent before I could even see it in Redbox or on my demand channels.  It did not disappoint and Christopher Walken was the best...have a new crush on Colin Farrell too.
Not a great movie. Nothing entirely wrong with the movie, but half way through I started wishing I had of gotten something else. Not a quality movie. Blah

I gave this a four-star "I like it" rating because I did like it; didn't love it, and it was better than a three-star "ehh" rating. It has a great cast, and they all play their roles well. No spoilers here, but I will say that the plot is fairly creative, although a bit clumsily executed and, maybe it's me, but there were certain parts I figured out in the first ten minutes. Still, it was nice to see how they combined all of these diverse talents into a watchable film. I won't go through the cast here, or what they did, specifically, because part of the fun I derived from this movie was how the cast was introduced, and how they fit into their roles. Suffice it to say that it's one of those rare movies of recent vintage that didn't make me question whether it was worth the rental price. Candidly, I'm not sure I'd pay to own it, but as a one-time rental on Amazon Direct (or if you can get it for $5), it's worth it. Fair warning: my wife did fall asleep within the first 15 minutes despite a fair amount of action and blood-shed. Just wasn't her cup of tea, even though she is usually a fan of both blood and action. This has both, just not in a style that suits everyone.
Great movie! had me enticed from begingng to end with lots of laughs in-between! two thumbs up on an awesome movie

Seven Psychopaths was smart and very funny with a few unexpected twists, which was great because few movies are unpredictable these days. It wasn't exactly what I expected, but was still a great movie that I'd recommend!
Sam Rockwell, Chris Walken, Woody Harrelson, Colin Farrell...you can't get a better group of kooky characters than that. Must see.
I thought this would be a little more funny.  A little too bloody.  But somehow I liked the quirky ending.
Good quirky fun. I really enjoyed it. The cast was excellent and the story was unique and interesting. Don't know why it didn't do better in the box office.

I rented this movie because the previews were funny, and there were several well-known actors starring in it.  However, it seems that ALL of the good parts of this movie were used to make the trailer.  Not worth the rental fee.

I really like Christopher Walken and Colin Farrell, so I would have watched it, no matter the reviews read.  It starts with a good story then pretty much turns bizarre and unlikeable. I don't understand why anyone would give this movie 4 plus stars. I rated it as 'ok' but in my opinion, it's really a 2-1/2. If you have absolutely nothing else to do and aren't tired, and there is nothing else to rent - well - why not, it's only $5.00.

I really liked this movie.  There was a lot of violence in it but what do you expect from a bunch of psychopaths! It wasn't you basic mob movie or shot them up it really had some suprising twists and turns and was in many places very funny.  I LOL'd many of times.  I hope it wins some awards because this movie is great.

Just mindless violence for violence sake. May appeal to people in Southern California but does not have any redeeming quality to me. Written by 13 year olds in a gun, blood and absurdity sandbox? One of the many films that I do not finish watching and lament the time wasted in front of it. Wish the rating system had negative star options as in this p.o.s. deserves -5 stars.
the movie was way different than I thought it was going to be, the previews/trailers made it seem a whole other movie
Don't rent this movie. There is really nothing funny about it at all( unless you find violence somehow funny). That was biggest waste of time and money I have experienced in a while.
I was surprised and engaged by the plot twists in this. I would label this as much a black comedy as action drama. Casting of roles made a huge difference.

If it was to appeal to those that like the over abundance of blood and sawing bodies than I guess this is your kind of twisted flick. I myself find this kind of movie distasteful and detrimental to society as it makes humor and mockery out of human pain and suffering. For example the consoling of someone crying and telling them it will be ok only to shoot them.....is that comedy.............I would just call this a waste of time

Finally, someone has made an action movie that does not put me to sleep.  Character driven and with a clever, original script I found this was the perfect movie for me.  If you think everything that could ever be done in an action film (or a bromance for that matter)  check out this film. A true adult action film with pico de gallo dialoge thrown onto a pork tamale cast.  What a yummy film.  Gobble gobble gobble!

I thought it was very funny and amusing and would like to see it again and maybe even buy it it was funny.

Sam Rockwell might have toned it down a bit, his ranting caused the urge to flick off the flick repeatedly.

Just seem to feel plain sorry for Colin Farrell, which is telling; as so does one of the other characters at the end of the film.

Runtime: 1 hour 51 minutes Funtime about 27 minutes
Just because a show is twisted doesn't mean I'll like it.  It was really really boring. Kind of  like a boring story within a boring story.

The acting in this movie was fine, but it was the very tired plot device of a writer who can't decide what to write.  This is invariably a neurotic and narcissistic exercise, with very little to reward the viewer.  There is no real plot, because the point is that the writer is blocked and can develop one.  In this case, there is also precious little humor or action, and quite a bit of gratuitous misogynism.  Who can believe that losers like these would be paired up with beautiful woman that they treat like scum?  All in all, an offensive waste of time or money.  The high rating on Rotten Tomatoes must be because some critics are enamored of the intellectual exercise of playing with the film medium itself.  If that's your bag, try the old movie Greaser's Palace.
This funny film is well written, has a great cast; a little bit "out there" & clever. It's extremely violent similar to Fargo or Django unchained.
Super slow. Super boring. By 45 minutes in I was wanting my rental money back. I can't even really call it a dark comedy because I think i chuckled once.
Entertaining movie. Sam Rockwell's performance made the movie. Definitely worth a watch. Reminded me of a Guy Richie type films.
Nothing special, but worth a few laughs.  Surprisingly violent at times.  And I like Christopher Walken in anything.  But I will probably have completely forgotten this movie by tomorrow.

Writer-director Martin McDonagh arrived on the scene with his brilliant "In Bruges" a few years ago.  It was different and heralded a unique new sensibility on the cinematic scene.  "Seven Psychopaths" is no less audacious but may teeter a little by the weight of it's quirkiness.  The conceit here is Irish screenwriter, Marty(Colin Farell) is blocked in delivering a script to his employers.  He has a title, "Seven Psychopaths", and a concept of a Buddhist psychopath but nothing has been transferred from pen to paper.  Ironically a couple associates of his Billy (Sam Rockwell) and Hans(Christopher Walken) have kidnapped the beloved Shih Tzu of a psychotic thug, Charlie (Woody Harrelson).  Marty finds himself waist deep in psychopaths while he bounces ideas about the subject with Billy and Hans.  The film has an interesting structure but sometimes you think McDonagh may be biting off more than he can chew.  You know you're not in Kansas anymore when Christopher Walken is the most normal guy in the room.  That said the film leaves an impression on you that it may gain momentum on repeat viewings.  As it stands I give the film an A for effort and a B for execution.

The characters looked interesting, the synopsis sounded like it had potential, but after nothing but spewing f words in the first 3 minutes of the money, I flicked it off, and tried to get Amazon to refund the money I wasted on rental.  How low has the American public gone in backing filth like this?
The acting is good but the story is a little disturbing. I am not a dark humor gal. It was not predictable just a little distrubing.
better then what people other wrote.  i was happy with it that is for sure.  not farrells best movie but at least it was different then the standard.

This project/movie is total waste of time and talent. I only got the movie because of Christopher Walken who is one of my favorite actors.

This is another simple story that ends up in a blood bath for really no reason in a poor and really pathetic attempt to imitate Tarantino.

Hans is an old washed-up con man who is now stealing dogs and then returns them to their owner for reward money. He gives the money to his wife who has breast cancer and needs it for treatment. Everything goes well until he steals the dog of Charlie, a psychopath gangster (Woody Harelson). The movie takes off and there is a lot, ...and I mean a lot of blood and unnecessary killing with a lot of shots to the head. The opening scene is a total imitation of a Tarantino movie. But after that it fails miserably and we are in for a boring 100 minutes (this is a long time to wait to the end when you already know what is going to happen and that #1 is also #7). I think that Martin McDonagh should give up in trying to imitate Tarantino and get his own style.

One star because I have to give it something and also because of Christopher Walken. Nothing to see, nothing will happen...The movie is so predictable that I knew from the first five minutes who is #1 and what will happen to him.

While it had an interesting concept of a movie within a movie, it just wasn't very good.
As another review ersaid, Colin Farrell played a similar character as In Brueges, but with out the charm and more whining.
As a film it didn't really pull together.
Let's hope that the director still has some good films in him.
not as good as I expected.  The movie seemed to just drag on.  Three stars is pushing it a little.
But stopped watching a third of the way in. The only thing that was remotely comical were the looks on the dogs face as the action swirled around him
The cast was great, the story line was fun, if not credible.  I personally don't like the "movie within a movie" genre, but it was entertaining.
the story line was weak, it was a bit slapstick, but not really a belly buster.  Watch this is you are a loyal fan only.
I just didn't like it and glad I olnly rented and did noy buy. You have yo be a psychopath to like it.

One of the stupidest screenplays ever.  Really an infuriating insult to one's intelligence.  I thought a film starring Colin Farrel, Sam Rockwell, Christopher Walken, Tom Waits and Woody Harrelson would have to be an engaging comedy, but this thing was a complete turkey.

This is an excellent movie with excellent actors.  I've always thought they should give an Academemy Award for the Actor or Actress who portrays the very best friend ala "Sam" to "Frodo" in Lord of the Rings.  "Billy" would be high up in the runnings this year.
All I am going to say is the cast did a phenomenal job, this movie will stay in my library to watch over and over again.  If you have any doubt as to whether it's worth watching...do it.

I saw this in a theater and watched the video on Amazon. I actually enjoyed it less the second time. The plot was thin, the acting adequate by most of the cast. Sam Rockwell stole the movie from others and Chris Walken was surprisingly tame and bland. The basic premise was ridiculous. There are plenty of better new movies worthy of watching.

Wow, am I disappointed I spend $3.99 renting this movie.  The cast are all great actors and I have loved many of their movies, but this movie is very poorly written and truly has no meaning.  It was so bad that I stopped watching (wasting my time!) this movie 1/2 way through.

Terrible movie one of the worst I have ever seen...these actors must really need the money to work in such a terrible film!

Seven Psychopaths is from the same director who made the great 2008 film In Bruges. Unlike most Tarantino-rip off movies In Bruges actually had some depth to the usual hitman comedy schtick as well as well done dark humor and a nice plot that ties everything together. Seven Psychopaths on the other hand seems like the director threw darts at a chart with random things and scrambled to put it together. "Ok I hit bunnies, gotta throw bunnies in there, ok I hit peyote, gotta throw that in there now", and it all comes out rather bland.

The main problem I had with Seven Psychopaths was that it was predictable. You'd think with a name like Seven Psychopaths it'd be a free-for-all, but instead you can tell who the main character is, who's going to die, who you should feel sorry for, yadda yadda. Another thing is besides Sam Rockwell (who puts in another great performance), none of them seem all that crazy. Colin Ferrel is basically the same self-loathing drunk from In Bruges, Christopher Walken is just his usual hammy self with a 'dark past'. Woody Harrelson is basically an A-hole, and he was really underplayed in this. An ambiguously gay guy who loves his little Shih Tzu more than life itself, what does he do for a living? Why is he so obsessed with that dog? You never really know, you just know he's emotionally unstable. I know there could've been some good jokes from his past, but alas, another missed opportunity. The other three psychopaths are barely in the movie, you have LOLSORANDOM psycho with his pet bunny, and the two women who aren't seen after the first half hour.

Some things worked, some things didn't. I liked the set up of a few losers in LA stealing dogs then returning them for the ransom, clever idea. I liked how Colin Ferrel was trying to write a movie based off this movie, there were some good jokes in it, even though the meta-commentary is starting to get old in movies. But then you get stuff like when they took peyote, and it added literally nothing into the film.

Now I was a few whiskey's deep when I watched this, so it's more than likely that I missed some things, but in general the movie feels half-baked, like all the ingredients are there, but they're not used well. It was enjoyable enough to watch but overall a sophomore slump for director Martin McDonagh. My advice would be next time keep the story more contained.

Was really looking forward to seeing the latest film from the director of In Bruges.  What a letdown this movie was.  Lacked the wit of the earlier film.  I wish I had waited for it to be shown on cable instead of renting it!
Twisted, violent, emotional, and an AWESOME story. I would highly recommend this movie. Psychopaths or Life Changers ? You decide.

I've enjoyed many psycho/buddy/action/quirky movies with the same actors before. This movie didn't hold my interest, however. Poor pacing and little chemistry among the actors while on screen together. Sorry, but it's a mess.

I love films that can say so much without actually saying anything at all. This movie is totally meaningful and thought provoking--although, judging by the reviews, common people may not get it the first time around! The acting is perfect and so is the screenplay. It's definitely a movie for cinephiles like myself. If you just like sappy formula films or cliche blockbuster action films, than you probably won't care much for this film because it will say too much for you.

Also, I love how the special features on the DVD are the EXACT SAME as the special features on the Blu-ray. Since I love special features and don't buy blu-ray, this was perfect for me!

but, I couldn't wait for it to be over.  I am a fan of Christopher Walken and will watch just about anything he is in that is billed as a comedy.  I confess, I just don't get this movie beyond the point that "violence doesn't solve anything". To say that, this movie was just way way too violent, especially towards women. I did like the dog; but this is not a comedy to me.

Everyone has an opinion(of course)Maybe it's me? I just think fans of movies sometimes miss the point, It's all entertainment. Even when A Movie in the beginning states "Based On A True Story" Keep in mind the Directors/Writers were not present in the real life situation when things were going down at the time. They have to create there own story from facts they research, to then make they're Art/Movie. With 7 Psychopaths of course being fiction, I thought it was just Great Fun! The cast was perfect.  Have more of an open mind everyone!

I absolutely LOVE this movie.  I saw it in the theaters when it came out and loved it then watched it last night and loved it just as much. It is hard to find a new story, and here is one.  Yes, it's silly and bloody but it is also deeply philosophical tale that puts our hypocrisy on blast.

The silliness and fun of Zombieland.  Reflects how cynical many of us with that last bit of hope that keeps us truly human.

It is slow, violent and bloody. I thought I was watching a Tarantino movie, it was a good Woody Harrelson venue but I was
disappointed in Christopher Walken. I was only able to make it half way through the movie.

So, this movie was billed as a comedy, the trailer and the name suggest that it might be a little dark, but it had some great actors. Wife was like "Hey, new comedy, great reviews, let's watch it" - we lasted almost 15 minutes. Be warned that this movie was anything but a comedy. In all fairness we did shut it off after the first two actors spring very graphic head leaks from unexpected bullets, and the next two actors slice themselves open from ear to ear - again in very gory fashion. LoL?? Seriously?? Don't get me wrong; I loved Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber Of Fleet Street, so it's not that I can't handle a little gore; but this movie was far from what it claimed and what we were expecting to see.. I really enjoyed this movie. There were twists and turns that kept it entertaining. I thought all the actors did a phenomenal job with their parts.

Roger Ebert's review of Seven Psychopaths is far better than the actual film. "Written and directed by Martin McDonagh ("In Bruges"), this is a delightfully goofy, self-aware movie that knows it is a movie. You've heard of a movie within a movie? I think this is a movie without a movie."
[...]

I tend to like dark, quirky movies, but I like them to make at least a little sense. This is more of a sense experiment writ large where the primary actors are better than the sum of their parts. This movie badly wanted to be smart and insightful and Tarantinoesque, but aiming for all three elements, it hit none of them. It was a glorious mess, and I don't mean that in a kind way. I'm glad I saw it, but can't recommend it.

As a big fan of "In Bruges" I went into this film hoping to enjoy it just as much.  I did.  This movie his hilarious, clever, and original.  Any fan of dark comedy should check this movie out, especially if you enjoyed "In Bruges".

I think this is the type of movie that some people get and others don't get it. I am in the latter group. It just was a mess. A real cute dog though! To me this movie was lots of talking and no real plot. I enjoyed seeing Colin Farrel playing such a wimp.

I bought this on blu ray thinking it would be great judging from the reviews. First of all, the acting was horrible, the plot was stupid. and nothing happened throughout 50 minutes. No chases, no explosions. just guys killing guys for no apparent reason. Not even Collin Farrell and Woody Harleson could save this movie from sucking. In other words, if you want to see it, rent it don't buy it. Chances are you will be disappointed!!!

This movie provides horrific scenes of gruesome murders and leaves you with these images stuck in your mind.  The story line of finding a kidnapped dog seemed to be added as an afterthought in an attempt to offer some kind of plot.

The world does not need this kind of violence offered as "entertainment".

I loved this film!
But am hard-pressed to explain why.  I mean what, really, is funny or entertaining about kill-crazed psychopaths and spurting, gushing blood?  When one gets right down to it, not a thing.
But that fact serves as a testimonial to the brilliance, the genius, that was brought to the making of "Seven Psychopaths."  I found it to be a riveting laugh-fest.
Granted, for me it bogged down a tad in its last quarter or so.  But that, in a way, was a good thing.  It gave me time to catch my breath.
"Seven Psychopaths" also features stellar acting.  Woody Harrelson was superb as one of the seven;  Christopher Walken also delivered, I thought, one of his best-ever performances; and what can I say about Sam Rockwell?  His work here should launch him as a major, in-heavy-demand star.
I do have one problem with this film, though.  As was the case with Freidkin's "Killer Joe," I'm hesitant to tell various people I know how much I enjoyed "Seven Psychopaths."  Because this sort of film certainly isn't going to be the cat's pajamas for everyone, and they might stop returning my phone calls.
A very funny movie that actually reminded me a little bit of Tarantino. Great humor and surprises throughout. Definitely worth a watch!

Part Hollywood insider piece, part action parody, SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS comes out of the gate charging full-throttle.  Well, actually the opening scene features two hitmen talking about shooting people in the eyes.  We then seque into the story of three friends: struggling screenwriter Marty (Colin Ferrell); con artist loser Billy (Sam Rockwell); and spiritual, devoted husband Hans (Christopher Walken).  When the latter two kidnap the beloved dog of a mafia leader (Woody Harrelson), all three forced to run, heading toward that inevitable climactic shootout.

Martin McDonagh's previous effort, IN BRUGES, will probably go down as a classic.  SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS just might as well.  It's got a little more edge than BRUGES (more blood, too); parts of the film almost feel Tarantino-ish.  And yet, the film is wholly McDonagh's; never once does it feel like he's ripping anybody off.  In fact, his humor and parody are both spot-on, so much so that they come off as unique, even though they really aren't.

It doesn't hurt that he's assembled a great cast.  Farrell returns from BRUGES, doing his slacker charm thing (this is a solid performance, but far from his best).  Rockwell steals the show as Billy; he's comedic yet unstable, an unpredictable tour-de-force that helps cement the film together.  Walken brings a surprising depth to his performance, while Harrelson oozes menace while being absolutely hilarious.  The film also features fantastic smaller performances from a range of contributors: Harry Dean Stanton, Linda Bright Clay, Michael Pitt, Michael Stuhlbarg, Gabourey Sidebe, and especially Tom Waits as a rabbit-cradling lunatic.  SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS, like its predecessor, features that ultimate trifecta in filmmaking: cast, script, and direction.  We'd expect nothing less from a Martin McDonagh film.

The story, cast, and dark humor really sparked my interest when I saw the trailer for Seven Psychopaths. It is quite a funny and charming story with a rather large entertainment factor and a little less of character development and story. The idea of the film is very simple yet has a more complex development than your average movie.

The cast is great and while I felt there was not enough character development for anyone, it was still funny and entertaining. The plot twists were not very surprising and the ending was a little anti-climatic, but over-all it was a fun movie and I'm glad I blind bought it as I'll be watching it again.

The PQ and AQ are very decent, but not the best I have seen. The Blu-ray disc is a little light on the extra's, however this is not the type of movie I could watch hours of bonus content.

Recommended for at least a rent, but if the price is right a purchase would be worth it.

I bought this movie hoping the Ultraviolet would have some sort of way of downloading  thru i-tunes, being a mac user myself, but NO,  you have to download some Microsoft program to handle the sony download, and I just do not want that on my computer,  and I like a digital copy so I can play it thru my apple tv. I should have saved the money and just bought the download from I-tunes and save the irritation  of another lame Sony product.  Oh yeah the movie is cool though.

Starring Colin Farrell, Sam Rockwell, Woody Harrelson, Tom Waits, Christopher Walken and written/directed by Martin McDonagh this film tells the story of Marty Faranan (Farrell), a screenwriter trying to finish a film he's writing entitled Seven Psychopaths. His friend Billy (Rockwell) tries to help motivate him to finish his film but Marty lacks motivation. He can't seem to get his thoughts straight enough to complete the screenplay so Billy (being the friend that he is) takes an ad out in the paper calling all "psychopaths" in to tell their story. In the meantime Billy and his friend Hans (Walken) have a scam going where they kidnap or "borrow" dogs then collect a reward when the return them. As it turns out they "borrow" the wrong dog and now a gangster named Charlie Costello is after them (including Marty) to get his dog back. Marty comes to a startling revelation about Billy and Charlie is STILL after his dog. With the chaos around him, Marty starts to question his screenplay and the direction to take with it.

Lately I've purposely been watching movies without watching trailers or reading a synopsis. I miss the days when you could watch a film and be completely surprised at the plot. This was one of those films. With a title like Seven Psychopaths I expected a bloodbath similar to Smokin Aces. I was so wrong. It turned out to be a story about a man at odds with himself and his story. Sure the film had some violence and shootouts but it felt like it was in the background of everything. It was mainly about him just trying to find inspiration and to write something that hadn't been done before. McDonagh brought the dark humor he did in In Bruges but with an action filled twist. I thought Colin Farrell was hilarious in this. Usually you think of him as a badass but in this film he was reduced to a kitty cat that seemed to be scared of just about everything and so unsure of himself. It really was a good change of pace for him and it shows his versatility. Walken was Walken. He usually plays the same type of character with the same comedic rhythm and timing but for some reason it doesn't get old. His role was in my opinion the most heartbreaking but even with the seriousness that it called for at times he still provided the one liners and idiosyncrasies that only he can bring to the table. Harrelson plays ruthless very well. Add dark humor to it and it makes for the perfect character in this film. To me, his attachment to his dog I found pretty funny and the way his gun keeps jamming throughout the movie. After watching the film twice I really do think they gave Rockwell some of the best lines and moments. It's funny that I'm even saying this but he played a psychopath with a heart of gold. The crazy things he did, he did them all to try to help a friend even if they were a bit maniacal. My complaint: I wish they would've given Tom Waits a bigger part. With his character I felt like there was a bigger story to be told there. (If) they make a sequel then I think that would be the perfect opportunity to explore his character more.

Seven Psychopaths
is Martin McDonagh's follow-up to his quirky 2008 hit, In Bruges.  McDonagh is making a name for himself as his two films complement each other nicely and provide a roadmap for the type of director McDonagh aspires to be.  Like Tarantino or Hitchcock, McDonagh strives to make films about similar types of characters viewed through a similar societal lens.  Awareness seems to be McDonagh's trademark.  His characters are flawed, yet keenly aware of these flaws.  His scripts are dark, yet this darkness is carefully tempered by his films' awareness of the fact that they are films, as his characters are always interacting with the film industry in some way.  This awareness allows the viewer to enjoy his films on multiple levels, first on a narrative level and again on a satirical level that tries to provide commentary on humanity through the narrative.

In the case of Seven Psychopaths, McDonagh turns his focused lens on an unfocused, alcoholic screenwriter, Marty (Colin Ferrell).  Marty is struggling to write a film called Seven Psychopaths and turns to his friends and their acquaintances for inspirations on ways to characterize his seven different psychopathic characters.  What follows is a wild series of events that lead Marty down the literal Psycho-Path to self-realization.  As his characters become fleshed out, Marty starts to see that he's living a detached life.  His detached life is illustrated by the flaws of his screenplay.  Marty's writing is not authentic.  He borrows from other people's lives to write his characters, and his tragic personal life causes his women characters to be nothing but fragile stereotypes.  His relationship is in shambles, his inspiration is drying up, Marty is desperate for a motivation, and thanks to a mixed up con-gone-wrong by his dog kidnapping grifter friends, Hans and Billy (Christopher Walken and Sam Rockwell), this motivation comes in the form of an LA underground gangster (Woody Harrelson) who is seriously upset about his kidnapped Shi-tszu.

Seven Psychopaths is a busy film and it is also McDonagh's most brutal.  There is so much going on that its stars only have a matter of minutes to shine.  Standouts are Rockwell and Walken.  Rockwell's Billy is a fast-talking idea man.  He's relentless and firing on all cylinders in every scene.  Walken plays Hans, who is much more relaxed than Billy, but equally fun to watch.  Walken is doing a Walken impression here, which is basically what people have come to want from him in this phase of his career.  Regarding its brutality, from the opening scene, the film's tone is quite clear.  While trailers might lead one to believe that the dog kidnapping plotline is central to the story, it is actually a very minor element.  The majority of the film's 109 minutes explores exactly what happens when the "inmates take over the insane asylum."  Desert shootouts, sadistic serial killers, and revenge killings pepper the action of the film.  Seven Psychopaths feels inspired by the independent films of the 90s.  As it unfolds, it is reminiscent of 1994s Floundering or 1995's Living in Oblivion not in plot (or in casting James LeGros), but in its meaning.  These films blend the effects of fantasy and reality in a compelling way, creating a very enjoyable movie.  If only James LeGros could have shown up as an eighth psychopath!  B+

SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS (2012) is a wickedly delightful, somewhat violent, black comedy, written and directed by Martin McDonagh, whose previous film was the equally wickedly delightful, if slightly less violent, IN BRUGES.

Colin Farrell, who also starred in IN BRUGES, plays an alcoholic Hollywood screenwriter who is having trouble formulating his current assignment, a screenplay entitled "Seven Psychopaths".  His best friend, a somewhat unstable actor (Sam Rockwell) with a penchant for punching out casting directors, realizes that Colin just needs some inspiration, so he makes it possible for him to meet some real psychopaths.

Sam's "day job" is that of a dog kidnapper.  He and partner Christopher Walken steal people's dogs, then return them for the posted reward.  Unfortunately, they make the mistake of snatching the pooch of a crazed gangster (Woody Harrelson), who will stop at nothing to get his beloved animal back.

SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS is a film of multiple layers; therefore no written synopsis would do the twist-filled plot justice.  Certain scenes are set in the real world, while others are sequences from the "Seven Psychopaths" screenplay in progress as imagined by Farrell, or Rockwell or Walken, both of whom have been invited to collaborate on Colin's work.

Farrell is certainly a fine actor, but in this outrageously funny film he essentially plays straight man to Rockwell, Walken,  Harrelson and Tom Waits, all of whom, in this writer's opinion, should have been Oscar-nominated  for their portrayals of hilariously demented characters .

Martin McDonagh's deft dialogue is a laugh-out-loud riot.

Extras on the Blu-Ray and DVD from Sony Pictures Home Entertainment include six "Behind the Scenes" featurettes.

 Michael B. Druxman

Seven Psychopaths is a complex, witty, well acted (and violent) film concerning the misadventures of a talented but lazy screenwriter (Colin Ferrel) as he tries to write a blockbuster film about...yes...seven psychopaths...and world peace...and finds his life slipping out of control.

Like "In Bruges" (to which other reviewers have compared it) this film does not fit easily into any mold. It's both a dark comedy where the humor sparkles against strong violence, and an action film woven around an unlikely theme of redemption. It contains elements that are heart-breaking, gratifying, horrifying, and even excessively silly. A grab bag which is not going to appeal to everyone but left me feeling I'd seen one of the best movies of the year.

*** This review may contain spoilers ***

  'Seven Psychopaths' is by Martin McDonagh, an alleged 'noted' playwright turned screenwriter. A better appellation for Mr. McDonagh, would simply be, 'hack'. One can surmise that McDonagh's 'psychopaths', is an attempt to write some kind of farce or 'black comedy', satirizing hyper-violent action movies. McDonagh fails to grasp the mechanics of farce, in which you're permitted the outrage, without the consequences.

  One lame example of this, is the exploding head sequence. As it's a scene that's part of a fantasy, the exploding head is outrageous, but without consequences. Hence, it qualifies (barely) as farce. Not so the entirely tasteless scene, where Charlie guns down Hans' cancer-stricken wife, Myra, in the hospital. It's a scene that is outrageous in its cruelty and with consequences--within the context of the story, we have no reason to feel this event is amusing in the least. Han's passive reaction to the murder of his wife is perhaps also supposed to be humorous (in a passive-aggressive way), but I found the entire sequence involving the shooting of Myra, to be completely inappropriate, and indicative of McDonagh's complete misunderstanding as to how to craft a successful satire.

  The ugliness of McDonagh's humor (reflected in the Myra sequence) is borne out by Mike LaSalle's review in the SF Chronicle. He writes: "In the end, "Seven Psychopaths" is an immersion in ugliness and violence, barely relieved by wit. It's not a comment on an ugly, crazy world, nor is it a response to an ugly, crazy world. It's just ugly all on its own - and not nearly as crazy as it should be."

  There's also a sense that McDonagh wants everything, 'both ways'. As much as he seeks to mock the hyper-violent action genre, he is also seduced by it. Kenneth Turan writing in the LA Times senses this: "Like screen writing Marty, who wants to pen a violent psychopath tale that is also life-affirming, this film wants to deliver genre satisfactions while simultaneously subverting them. It's a difficult maneuver, and "Seven Psychopaths" doesn't quite pull it off." Ann Hornaday in the Washington Post also echoes McDonagh's infatuation with violence: "But the film also begins to feel like a case of a director getting to revel in the very thing he's reviling." Kevin Jagernauth, writing in The Playlist, agrees with the 'both ways' theory: "Boasting lots of gun-play, a big extended cast of stars willing to play along and a less witty, broader sense of humor, McDonagh tries to have it both ways by playing to the cheap seats while pointing out how absurd it is at the same time."

  The 'Seven Psychopaths' plot revolves around Colin Farrell's character, Marty Faranan, an alcoholic screenwriter, who suffers from writer's block, and only has gotten as far as composing a title for his next work. Marty's best friend, the unemployed actor Billy Bickle (Sam Rockwell), suggests that he use the 'Jack of Diamonds' serial killer as his Psychopath #1 for the screenplay (it turns out later that Bickle is actually the Jack of Diamonds killer, a murderer who kills other killers). Not all the psychopaths are real life characters; Marty dreams up perhaps the only interesting character in his pantheon of killers--a Quaker who stalks his daughter's killer and in an O'Henry-like twist, drives the killer to suicide, and follows him to hell when he slits his own throat.

  McDonagh intentionally makes his characters as unlikeable as possible, including Bickle and Hans (Christopher Walken) who steal dogs from their unsuspecting owners, only to return them to collect the reward money. The break into Act II occurs, when Bickle and Hans steal a Shih Tzu that belongs to Charlie Costello (Woody Harrelson), a sadistic gangster, whose bent on retrieving the pooch at any cost.

  If this isn't enough, Marty's ad in the paper for more psychopaths, brings Zachariah Rigby, who used to go around the country with a girl, Maggie, who he saved after she was imprisoned in a serial killer's basement. In true Tarrantino fashion, the couple are seen in flashbacks, going around the country, hacking the hands off notable serial murderers, including the Zodiac Killer. Zachariah has Marty promise that he'll place a notice in the screen credits at the end of 'Seven Psychopaths', so he may re-unite with the long lost Maggie.

  The denouement of 'Seven Psychopaths' occurs when Marty, Hans and Bickle drive out to the desert. In a completely absurd scene, Charlie, drives out alone to meet them, carrying only a flare gun. When Bickle shoots Charlie in the back, it looks like it's curtains for him, but in a short amount of time, Charlie reveals it's only a 'flesh wound' and Marty attempts to save him by driving him back to town.

  I won't go into the ending since by this time, we've long lost caring for any of the characters. McDonagh's idea of humor is to stretch both his characters and situations to the maximum level of absurdity. This strategy backfires, as we soon come to realize that it's not enough to offset McDonagh's guilty pleasure: the love of violence!

I saw this a few days ago and really enjoyed it. The trailer I think is a bit deceiving about what this movie is really about which threw me off a little bit for the first half of the movie. It's one of those movies you won't fully understand till about mid way through which I think is a good thing. I don't want to spoil too much about the movie but essentially it's about Colin Farrell's character writing a movie about Seven Psychopaths (Hints the name) and Sam Rockwell who kidnaps Woody Harrelson's beloved Shih Tzu. Somehow all of that stuff ends up being connected in an odd and interesting way.

Seven Psychopaths is a very enjoyable movie if you stick with it till the end. It may feel a little odd and all over the place when it first starts but it all starts making sense later on in the movie. Watch the film for yourself and see if you like it because it's a little different than a lot of movies out there.

Marty (Colin Farrell) is a screen writer with writer's block. He is attempting to write a screenplay called "Seven Psychopaths" a grindhouse without any killing or grindhouse action. His friend Billy Bickels (Sam Rockwell) offers him ideas, which aren't exactly all fictional. Billy steals pets for a living while his partner Hans (Christopher Walken) takes them back for the reward. One of the pets he steals belongs to crime boss Charlie Costello (Woody Harrelson). The tag reads, "Return to Charlie Costello, or you wil f@#$ing die."

All this is going on while a real psychopath is killing Charlie's guys. The movie includes parts of the screenplay which ties things together.

This is a smartly written grindhouse which satirizes over-the-top grindhouse scenes with big shoot outs and exploding heads. At one point Hans remarks, "psychopaths get tiresome after awhile." Actually they don't on screen. Great film for grindhouse/ Tarantino type fans. Good dialogue.

Parental guide: F-bombs, brief sex, nudity (Christine Marzano)

To borrow a term from the movie, it's got "layers"! With a fantastically talented cast playing quirky and unique characters, Seven Psychopaths is indeed a wild ride. McDonagah has a way of keeping the mood light, despite some very violent scenes, making the movie enjoyable even while it's disturbing. Add to that the world's cutest Shih Tzu, and you have a potential cult-classic!

The same director and screenwriter who made IN BRUGES with Colin Farrell teams with him again in this film.  This time Farrell plays an alcoholic Irish screenwriter in Hollywood who gets the idea of writing a screenplay called SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS. There are many ironies waiting for him in tackling this screenplay as his good friend, played by Sam Rockwell, who seems normal, really is totally off the wall and up for anything.  Much as I liked Farrell, Rockwell almost walks off with the whole movie because he is so good as this off the wall character.

Christopher Walken costars with these two as an older friend. For a change, he seems normal in comparison to them. They increasingly draw him into the action and he gets caught up with the SEVEN PSYCHOPATHS screenplay as well.

Not to be left out, Woody Harrelson is the local crime boss who is distraught because his dog has been stolen. His dog, hilariously, is one of these toy Chinese breeds.  The dog stealer is Rockwell and, even better, the dog likes Rockwell better than Harrelson. Harrelson is alternately vicious and distraught over his lost dog.

I really enjoyed this film.  It was a very good evening's entertainment.  If you liked IN BRUGES, you will also like this.

You see the cast.  You know Walken is in there.  How bad could it be?  VERY bad.  To the point that you feel the people who made the movie have revealed more about themselves and how vile their thought process is than they intended.  Bad in a way that makes you sorry you gave up the time to see it.  And I am certainly capable of enjoying a bad movie.  This movie is not like that.

It's entertaining, even promising, for about 20 minutes.  From that point you are simply not watching a comedy, period.  Don't let anyone tell you otherwise.  It is trying to be clever so hard it has back-sweats.  And there's lots of bad effort to steal from other movies that I'm sure the filmmakers thought this movie was going to resemble.  You can almost hear them in the pitch meeting saying that it's going to be just like FILL-IN-THE-BLANK.  There is an attempt at "Snatch".  Nope.  It uses self-reference, "Adaptation" style, to no effect whatsoever.  They're ripping off everyone from Tarantino to Coppola, all for naught.  The only interesting element is that the film confesses that it's going to disappoint you even as you're watching it degenerate.  "Dark" comedies still have to be funny.  At least a little.  If you watch this, when it ends you will sigh.  And hang your head a little.  And you'll think to yourself, "Well, there's a hundred minutes of my life I will never see again..."

The story uses (mis-uses) some real world historical events in a manner than can only be described as shameful.  Really.  Seeing them utilized the way they are here only succeeds in making you want to take a shower. Additionally it demonstrates that the writer - who is Irish - does not have the faintest understanding of what these events mean to Americans.  And I want to be clear, none of these flaws are in and of themselves amusing.  You will not get a kick out of seeing the mistakes in tone and pace the way you can with some movies.  The effect here is more akin to seeing a bird with a broken wing; you wish all these actors had labored in a different project, and you especially come away with a stomach ache that Walken used some of his days being dragged through the mud on this project.  So to answer that question - NO it's not worth it because it's Walken.  You just feel bad for him, as he spits up the tripe composed by this bleary eyed and baffled writer and director.  To those comparing this in ANY way to a Coen Brothers film, SHAME on you.  I will promise you this, if you approach this trash expecting anything within a thousand miles of a Coen Brothers film you won't just be disappointed - you'll be angry.

So often the experience is one where you almost say out loud, "No, I am not going to go there with you, you don't know what you're doing".  Violence is expressed here in a manner that inadvertently tells you that this is what the people who made the film think of you.  That THIS is what they think YOU (Americans) enjoy.  How insulting.  Not just violence, but cruelty, displayed in a pointless callous way.  Women are especially disposable here, and again the film admits that.  Abbie Cornish is just wasted, and Linda Clay Bright is apparently only in the film to facilitate further audience abuse.  There is a reason this movie was so anticipated and was then a horrid flop; it is awful.  Just irredeemably AWFUL.  Watch and regret.  You have been warned.
I'm so glad I stumbled across this movie. I highly recommend!

Great movie!

Wow!  What just happened?  I've never been so confused by a movie in my life, but I know that it is good.  No, great.  An outstanding cast, really star studded and journeyman actors.  A beautiful script.  Just altogether amazing.  I think confusion is the appropriate reaction after one viewing of Seven Psychopaths, and anyone who says they understand it then, doesn't get it at all.  This is a movie that will make you work for your aha! moment, but it is worth it.  I shall return if I ever figure it out.

Meantime, watch this movie!
